(TL;DR) Fun and rewarding game that is a great in the horde survival genre. --- Watched some gameplay of this a long time ago and thought it looked fun, something like They Are Billions. The difficulty was pretty extreme early on but now that the game is fully out, it seems to be a lot better. The building is fun, exploring and fighting with your troops is rewarding, the challenge modes and infinite mode are awesome, the campaign (from what I played so far) is good, and lots more to love. What a shame. I immediately liked the style and the idea of the game when I saw it in my queue. I played Northgard to death and thought that this would be right up my alley. And it is. Or rather it was. This game is not for casuals or anyone not willing to invest hours per mission and optimize. The difficulty on "A walk in the park" is brutal. The missions require extensive micro play and need to be played optimally: Build order, rushing of specific upgrades, spamming specific units, doing specific tasks in order. If you imagined a quaint army builder / tower defense were half the joy is to watch the epic battles, prepare for disappointment. You'll be busy snowballing your economy to try to stay ahead of the difficulty curv..cliff. There is a reason why the achievements have such low completion rates. The tutorial alone will weed most people out. I understand that once somebody figures out the meta, the missions become trivial. Herein lies the problem of the game. It is either too hard or too easy with a hard lean towards the former. I hated multiplayer in Northgard - because you had to rush, had to do things in one specific optimal way or get stomped by the opponents. This game managed to recreate this feeling for pve - very successfully.

I *would* recommend the game, but it's a very marginal pass. They game becomes tedious fast, and i'm not even sure i'm halfway through. It's cutesy and fun as a colony-building, resource managing game, but it's also easy to lose track of your workforce because halfway through a map they start sucking resources dry really fast. That's one of my main problems with the game; it's GREAT at first when the numbers are small, but then you are asked to macro manage with micromanaging mechanics. That's not a lot of fun The same can be said about the fighting. It's fun and quantifiable at first but then the enemies start zerging you, and it's hard to keep track of all the variables or have proper management of the situation set up. On top of that, there's really no new unlockables. There *is* the option to change factions multiple times throughout the game which also branches out the storyline, but there are no "upgrades". Other similar strategy games (like Kingdom Rush, or TAB) have progress upgrades that unlock new/stronger equipment in later stages. Moreover, you do not have access to all of your assets from the beginning; the games limit you to certain units /towers at first which become stronger and more specialized as the game goes on. Here... neither of these happen. All your assets are available from mission one, and achievable from as soon as mission two. That stagnates the game, whose hours-long missions end up feeling tedious and tiresome. I like what is going on at first and I admire the effort that went into the branching campaigns. The scenes in-between missions are also very fun and give the game its own unique character. That said, i do feel tired after having played the missions; the game is a near-hit for me. I suppose i'm recommending it for what could have been. Lastly, highly addictive. Play at a risk

This game could be a 5 out of 5 if the difficulty was toned down. You should not be losing consistently on the easiest setting. The average person will probably quit this a couple levels in, but for some reason I keep trying despite constant failures.

so far, really enjoying it. its a very nice 50 50 blend of city management and growth, with equal amounts of medieval RTS (including growing your army as you want and not just commanding one given to you). i dont know how long a day is in this game but on the difficulty ive been playing and in the begining of the campaign, attacks from enemys come about every 5 days. so you have time to recover. the natural learning curve of this game is very smooth and easy on new players like myself. so far its really fun and its a little slower pace than some other RTS games. its really fun though when the enemy attacks from multiple sides and you need to micromanage and stretch your army thin between the fortifications. the army and city management in this game is very well desinged and fluid. even things down to the controls are designed very well so that there is very little overlap for controls when you want to do something with your army or your city or something else. this game so far is mostly focused on making fortifications first and army second. through the little experience i have so far i have seen very well that it is way more beneficial for the army to augment your defense when needed instead of it being the primary defense. if you want you can meet the enemy on a field and duke it out with just numbers and strategy. but its best to really on the walls and stuff to occupy the enemy so you can soften em up with large junks of rock being throw from catapults or hundreds of arrows being launched from your copious amounts of archers. anyway, so far really enjoying it and i will probably make another update after a few more hours ingame.

Don't be fooled by good artsyle and nice base mechanics - this game is horrible in what matters the most. Level design and tools it gives for the job. Campaign (Main chunk of content here) relies on YOU assaulting enemy bases (Compared to trailers which show you defending yourself from enemy forces). There are a few defense missions, yes, and they are the best. For assaults though... Let's give you some simple math as example. Trebuchet, a legendary siege known to most fans of medieval games. Enemy towers in last mission have up to 3000 HP (Range is about between 1200 and 3000). So you think "Well, it is trebuchet time". Only that... Trebuchets deal 45 damage per impact. 45 (!). So, to destroy *a* tower you need around 67 shots from trebuchets. And final level is full of these towers. And enemy will retaliate in the mean time, hell, good chance their own siege engines (With higher damage) will counter your trebuchets. And it is just an example of missions where you are the attacker. Game has plenty of tools for defensive playstyle, but barely for attacking. And there is planty of attacking to be done. Okay, you say. Then you still can micro all of these, right? No, you can't. Pathfinding and target finding is this game are worse than in Starcraft 1. Simple example - if you give attack move command, your units will attack empty walls and buildings, even if enemy units are around. Target priority "units > buildings" was solved decades ago for RTS, what is this? But then you might say "well then, just manually click what you want to attack". Only that units will always choose worst path for attacking, they will stack in each other, blocking attack pathes for on another. Overall, it is very *frustrating* experience. Games tries to be what it isn't, and thus falls apart. Bleh

Love everything about the game but it's to difficult. Every level requires multiple takes to figure out the one and only way to beat it. 50 hours in and it's gotten old, it's just not fun anymore, and there's no way to make it easier.

The game is fun for just a few maps, then it becomes too tedious. My main issue with this game is the constant need of grinding resources. All of them run out quickly and you need to constantly move your camps, storage etc, to keep the flow of resources flowing to feed your tech tree, defenses and troops. There is too much going on at the same time. It's important to keep a good level of tension otherwise the game becomes boring but tension all the time is just stress. There are no moments of peace, if you are not dealing with a wave you need to micro your troops to kill the enemies on the map to allow your workers to get more resources that are constantly running out. If you don't mind clicking everywhere hysterically then you may enjoy it. I quick fix I can suggest: wood, crops and fish x5, iron and stone x2, i.e: if a tree gives 100 wood change it to 500.

The game can be very addictive. The only critique I have is the undead portion of the campaign feels like it spikes significantly and without warning. I do want to see more survival options, but overall I love this game.

could be a good game .. but difficulty level jumps way too much even on easy difficulty level once you hit undead levels. Bosses wipe out whole groups of solders in 1 hit have to kite or bring back to base and let towers kill them.

What a wonderful game! I'm always down for a new RTS, this is very reminiscent of They Are Billions, only in a lighter more comedic tone with less OP individual units. It definitely scratches the itch for RTS mixed with Tower Defense. I highly recommend it, So you'll understand the loop: there is no ramp up through the campaign for new buildings or anything, it's always an individual race to level up to the third building level and create large defense obstacles between "mountains" to push enemies into small areas so you can use your god powers to wipe them out, your units are nominally stronger than the enemy but their numbers can quickly overwhelm you. Usually though you can usually take your time to do just upgrade at "leisure" with regular bandit raids throughout depending on your difficulty. The harder levels can be quite brutal though! The campaign doesn't have any special player buildings or considerations aside from enemy building/unit types, but there are some interesting wrinkles on a few of the missions that keep it fun and interesting. Also the comedy is well done if occasionally grammatically incorrect. The visuals are quite nice, I personally have some fairly robust computers so I've never had any issues with too many sprites or system lag, but I'm not sure about older systems. It's pretty cool to have a few thousand enemies attacking you though, I thoroughly enjoy setting up my 50 man squads behind walls loaded with archers and siege weapons. I give it a solid 8.5/10

I really wanted to like this game but there's just too many aspects going on at the same time trying to lose the game for you. You can't worry about building a decent base and walls when you have to go out and destroy troops and fortifications using completely brain dead troops, all while trying to harvest resources and provide food which there is never enough sources of. Oh and don't forget magic spells, a skill tree, and enemies that spawn out of the ground... oh, and cleaning up dead solders. One aspect slips and you flushed hours down the toilet. It really just seems like they kept adding aspects until the game became difficult. I love tower defense games but this one is overly involved to the point of being tedious, drawn out, VERY grindy, and frankly... boring. The waves are also completely unbalanced as first waves will have a few troops while later waves are endless from every direction. A cool attempt at something different, but a fail on many levels.
It's just boring. I've tried a couple times to get into it, but I just can't.

This game is challenging and fun. I love that there are multiple options you can take that impact the levels you play, this leads to many replay opportunities.

If you like playing a defensive game on Age of Empires, this game is for you! I'm not particularly skilled at RTS games, so the inclusion of a pause button makes this much more manageable and fun for a casual RTS fan, such as myself. I feel like the developers struck a nice balance between town management and troop deployment. I haven't touched the harder difficulties yet, (I've been playing on the Normal mode) but could see them being an option for those more skilled in the genre. So far, I'm really enjoying the campaign mode and the cut scenes are quite charming. All in all, definitely worth 15-20 dollars.

Die once, die some more, build defences, learn how to save-scum. 10/10 would not diplomacy again. Game is a lot of fun. It's quite challenging and scratches the base building and castle defence itch. The art style looks good. The mechanics are easy to grasp but takes some trial and error to master. The campaign has a witty 4th wall breaking and dry comedy style that does sometimes go overboard, but overall keeps the campaign engaging.
Papulta, enemy army is 30 times bigger than yours, would you like to Meteor strike? No, papulta, your enemy, not yourself.
It's fun and the decisions and endings are surprisingly satisfying. The biggest con for me is I just think it looks kinda ugly. Obviously your opinion may be different.

Super fun game. Way too hard though. I had about 200 hours into the pre-release. I could go forever on easy mode endless. Bought the game, and the second real campaign mission kicks my ass? On easy? I have been playing RTS's for 36 years, I'm no rookie. So, I can only imagine how tough it is for first timers. Please fix it.
very nice, remind me of Warcraft2 mixed with age of empire and perhaps with a good 3d engine. short review as of yet but was watching the latest 007 on prime.

Honestly i do have a skill issue but cmon, i dont wanna have to optimize my heart out on the easiest difficulty in order to avoid an unwinnable fight, great game if your up for the challenge but levels can take hours with some of the most annoying attacks, i mean it will just throw a load of tanky, high damage enemies at you that your catapults can barely do anything against, they destroy your walls, and demolish your army, and then wreck you. I just have a skill issue honestly but if you like a challenge, even on the easiest difficulty, then this game is for you as it plays well and can be very rewarding. I am leaving a positive review because it isnt bad, just brutal
Its a fun little game. gets better with every release!

I had such hope for this game during early access. The first two missions were funny and challenging and I thought, "Okay, I know exactly what this game is going to be". Then it got released. I played mission 3. And immediately failed. Thought maybe this was a fluke. Okay, lets try it again - and again, immediately failed. Literally followed the tutorial and failed. This isn't a skill issue, from what I can tell, either. The difficulty for this mission cannot be changed (unlike other difficulties for other missions.) I don't understand what the dev was thinking. This entire game, gated by this one god awful mission design, and I cant even access it. I'm going to be submitting a refund request. I doubt that I'll get it, but this is awful enough that I literally cannot proceed with the game. What a rip off this was.
Good

tldr sweet mechanics player friendly UI player empowering design brutal testing if you grasped things like ''build massive defences & armies or die'' rambling details something to compare it with ? say stronhold but larger scale example of sweet mechanics most of them is pure ingame resource based no silly ''only 5 of these'' , you got the iron & gold ? well go hogwild with knights then mate! but likewise there are delicious 'organic' details sprinkled in such as for example , your citizens needs food or they start die yes ? ...so do your soldiers ,and the dead are ehm , reeeeestlesssss hehehe example of player friendly ui you chose if you want to decide what buildings gets repaired , oooooor , just declare builders to repair everything they can reach example of player empowering design as stated , no forced iron man mode , you got 100% control of your classic style saved games etc example of the brutal design as some others wrote ''there is a serious difficulty spike at mission 3 , suddenly you go from'clean map with your little squad' to 'here comes THE HORDE!'' but , this is honestly not as much of a 'spike' as some claims compare it to stronghold and those that only ever played vs the rat ''aka the most incompetent of the AI's'' and those that played vs the other ones or humans , one group will be baffled that they are resisted at all the other just says dam , i was a bit slow on getting those walls and crossbows up and , vastly superior to for example they are billions NO FORCED IRON MAN CRAP! if you are trying decide between these two games pick this instead YOU ARE IN CONTROL OF YOUR SAVED GAMES ETC , only down side is you have to make extra 'users' to explore alternative decision paths in the campaign but thats trivial

Very good game. Multiple difficulties makes it so game can be very hard if you want it to be. Campaign was fun. Challenge modes are very fun.

absolute banger

I *STRUGGLE* on A Walk in the Park difficulty, and that's the lowest difficulty avaliable. I'd really like, if not easier difficulties or updates making lower difficulties on campaign missions easier, than maybe some way to enable cheats like spawning in troops, or resources. Anyway, great game, thanks, devs.

It's like Stronghold but the campaign is much harder... It's fun and challenge enough, but there are some problems. The main problem is that the army always attack the useless units like walls, not the enemy or the catapult. I need to take care about economy and control my army to attack the damn catapult on the fort... But the enemy will do the same, so you can build lots of useless buildings to hold the enemy. I liked the game before the release, now i like it even more. You have boss battles in this game, they have death metal intros. 10/10

solid fun. real challenge

There's some technical jank for some reason, recently, when running full screen but runs under borderless Window. I have an AMD 7900 XTX on Windows 10 Pro. As for game play, it's definitely a fun game to play. I love the waves and the free-form way you can build your fortress, it feels like Stronghold 2 with magic The units aren't exactly animated individually. For "movement" a lot of unit just kinda bounce along the ground, a lot of them do have an attack animation. This game is a technical feat, however, and for the scale that you can operate at, it's really really great to play. This is definitely a game that can be tough to master initially.

Fun game. Gets a bit repetitive (I have only played campaign) but its very challenging. Wish there was more of an unlock process, the game gives you everything on level 2 or 3 but you are always starting from scratch on each level. Its a bit of a snowball effect mechanic to rush through the same stuff until you can build an effective army. If you fall behind the enemies snowball you're toast.
It doesn't suck. Its not really buggy. You'll get your money's worth out of it.
needs better balancing and the devs need to stop with the diary BS.
The game is very basic, but it is a lot of fun. The graphics are not the best, but that allows for armies that are very epic in size.

game has some serious flaws that require immediate attention from this dev team. The random enemies appearing in the middle of your city is an absolute joke! Not only that, but if the enemy is behind a building, you CAN"T HIT IT! Resources are so scarce, I have never got to lvl 3 town hall. The only way to get it is through market. HAHAHA! Amazing. Your units can't even hit a target you tell it to hit. Nightmare general is ridiculously OP for this game. Overall, a game that has serious balance problems.

they are billions, but much better in nearly every aspect. completed the campaign on "challenge accepted" and had fun through the whole run. some missions are harder than others and require some restarting and adjusting, but none are unfair. my only gripes: [list] [*] cutscenes are very slow paced. an option to immediately show the whole text by clicking a button is dearly missing. [*] pathfinding could be better. my units tend to clump together such that only a few units at the front can attack while those behind just keep running into the first ones instead of walking around them. Surrounding a building or unit is nearly impossible without lots of micromanaging [/list]
Pretty intricate and interesting. Give it a go if you love games like 'Billions'

Very satisfying RTS with a lot of moving parts on screen. My only gripe is that it is beyond ludicrously difficult even on the easiest setting but its nothing you can't overcome with skill and dedication and a few hours of restarts on a level.
Incredibly fun, lots of replayability and choices with a well scaling difficulty.
greatest game ive ever played not lying not capping not quizzying not rizzleing beats halo wars for me, chess with action
Great RTS

The game has a really fun mixture of building and fighting. Even reminds me a little bit of Settlers 3+4 mixed with stronghold and tower defence. It is is in a decent state, but not perfect. I hadn't had any crashes so far, but the pathfinding of the settlers has bricked quite a few times, when the settlement got bigger. The campaign is fun so far, I have played through it about halfway this far. To those people that complain about the difficulty, I get where you are coming from. I don't think, that the game itself is too hard, but it does a pretty bad job of teaching you to scale up your base. I had to watch a video of people playing an the hardest difficulties, to see their build order. After that, it became the "walk in the park" it promised, but this should be tought through gameplay and not by watching other people. A fix for that could maybe be a small prologue campaign that serves as an extended tutorial, that forces you to build larger economies. Right now, the fourth (if memory serves right) mission of the campaign, where you have to build those boats, is the first mission, where you have to expand to townhall lvl3, having to use the market and whilst beeing under pressure, Which results in quite a difficulty spike, until you have figured those mechanics out. The fact, that the maps are randomly generated, doesn't really help with it, when you are already struggling with figuring out your build order and then also having to adapt it to the maps surcomstances on the fly. I understand, why that is but maybe give an option to play with a fixed seed on lower difficulties? All in all a fun game, when you have figured out how it works. that "Figuring out" process is needlessly frustrating, but the game still has a lot of potential to get even better, then it already is.

Fresh and fun! It's a well achieved combination of simple textures, satisfying mechanics and multiple re-playability features. It's a small learning curve tho i'll point it out, you rapidly figure out what's the best course of action and as long as you're efficient it's enjoyable even on an higher difficulty. If you like RTS / colony sim it's a nice addition to your collection! Update : the campaign is very fun
YES

So much fun! Perfect RTS / Economy building / Tower defence blend with a lot of humour in the campaign which is really huge and 3 different branches for replayability. I play the whole game on ultra hardcore difficulty, it's extremely difficult but that's how I want it to be

i love rts games and no matter what i try i cant get past the fucking bloody butcher part no matter if i build walls or what theres just not enough time before waves start pounding ya the food shortage makes too impossible to have too many troops, civilians, or workers. i want my money back this isnt worth the fucking frustration!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Great game, hope will have DLC or more content !!! <3

Around mission 8 this game turns into the more stressful moments of an RTS like SC2 except they never stop and the games take 3+ hours. There's a cool magic system except the game doesn't give you a way to reliably get the resource for it until the last tech tree. Visibility is atrocious until tech tier 2 so your first minimap vision of an attack is a single red pixel about 2 seconds before it starts destroying your buildings.

Very strange game. It copies they are billions and tries to give a new take on the game but has a lot of bloat that is not needed and the game just does not flow well. The game is filled with a lot of small things, not being able to rebind attack-move but have lots of rebinds and even a joke rebind. A notification system but you cant select multiple builds from that notification system. A market system with a checkbox for you to trade right away but not have that for the research system that works the same way. Too much bloat where everything can be upgraded even though it doesnt really add anything to the game. The game would be better if it got more simplified and focused on things that actually matter. Dont copy just the idea of They are Billions, you should also try to copy its great pacing and gameplay instead of half assing it. Edit: After getting 10 hours into the game I got to the tower mission where you actually get attacked and the game became much better. It should have been like this from the start. I will change to recommend if they address the issues I had before. Edit2: Attacking fortresses does not feel good in this game and in the last mission for some reason the devs went extra hard on this. The last mission is terrible.

The enemy clumps up. I send a ray of holy crystal lighting their way. The little figures scream and ragdoll all over the place as they are hit. I get seratonin pumped straight into my bloodstream. Good game.

Don't let the simple graphics fool you. This game has depth. And a cheeky sense of humor that will keep you coming back.

This game is a fun blend of classic RTS, base building, and tower defense. The campaign is surprisingly dynamic with several paths to play through, each with their own quirks. The game overall is more challenging than I expected, with an emphasis on learning how to balance resource gathering, exploration, building defences, and assembling your army all while waves of enemies periodically try to ruin your existence. I highly recommend this game if you're a fan of classic RTS games like AoE, C&C, etc.

I love the art style, the simplicity of the game, and the challenge of most of the missions. I loved fighting the undead since they were the only unique faction you face. The other's all were the same with a different coat of paint. The last mission might be one of the most tedious, boring experiences I've ever had gaming. The only strategy that seemed to work was turtling with trebuchets. If you're looking for They are Billions meets Age of Empires then this is for you. I wouldn't buy this full price though, it lacks progression and depth. This game could be an awesome entry to the RTS genre but with so many people complaining about the difficulty even on easy, I don't think it is. I finished the game on the normal difficulty and had to replay missions multiple times, I enjoyed doing that, but I can see how that would put so many people off of playing it all the way to the end.
Fun and simple game. Highly recommend.

This is my first RTS and I've struggled hard on Ultra-Hardcore difficulty (difficulty tier 3 of 5) and I feel like it's been a great way to learn and I've had such a blast just trying hard and learning difficult lessons. Currently almost 100 hours in and barely 6 missions in with no end in sight, with tons of branching campaign options. There was a choice on the first level to side with one faction or another, then there was an option of siding with one faction or another 5 missions in, then there was a branching option for which mission to take from a narrative perspective with full different missions on one branch or another, not just in name only. Love love love this game

Great game, love the style and the tower defence genre of gameplay, it's a lot of fun except for one glaring issue.... balance. The easy difficulty is too easy, as you'd expect, but notch it up by one level and welcome to getting steamrolled in record time by army after army. This was an issue over a year ago and I picked it back up this week to find that the issue, even though it is a regular complaint, has not been fixed. Seems like a really easy thing to fix as well. Would love to thumbs up this game, everything else is superb, but the balance really ruins it.

This game combines city-building with strategic defence, and it’s relatively easy to pick up, though it takes a few hours to fully master. Once you get the hang of it, maximising resources and planning becomes very satisfying. However, it does start to feel repetitive after around 15 hours or a few missions. I hope we can get some new buildings, new enemies, new resources etc. in the future. But I highly doubt that - took 2 years from early access to full launch...

Now that the game has reached 1.0 and has its full campaign its well worth a buy if you are looking for a less annoying version of "They are billions". Good clean simple city building with waves of attack and other objectives.

Tremendous strategic pause game. Excellent system within itself, very good micro and macro balance, excellent scaling for a more challenging experience. Obviously created with some love and attention to details regarding the tactical flow. Has a bit of humor in the storyline.

LOVING this game!! it's like Age of Empires, but with more convenient and intuitive mechanics, dynamic defenses, and a building mechanism that doesn't force you to micromanage, it lets you lust think freely and the builders do the rest.

This was hard to get into at first, being repeatedly brutalized by the un-dead, villagers and your own team takes its toll. Until you realize that this is ultimately a less apocalyptic but equally unforgiving tribute to/evolution of "They are Billions". Its a really solid game once you get the build order and figure out the unit hirearchy. I've followed this through pre-release unable to progress, but now that the campaign is out there I'm on that mission to level up to nightmare mode. Highly recommend if you recognize that urge. For the price its worth it as is, but replayability will depend on how the door team see the franchise progressing - weekly challenges? more campaign DLC? Looking forward to seeing what comes next!

There are so many ways to go about doing the objective. For example, you can lock down your surroundings with massive towers filled with ranged troops and wait for the enemy or prepare a hunting party to eliminate the threats before they have a chance. This game has many different enemies and features that always make you experience something new every time you play.

Simple yet surprisingly deep singleplayer medieval RTS with large unit armies to control. I usually don't play these style of games but Door 407 made the mechanics simple yet complex enough for me to learn and enjoy playing the game, instead of requiring a college degree level of knowledge just to learn the basics on how to play and progress. It seems the Campaign has a learning curve after a few levels but I've spent more then 10 hrs in the Sandbox mode and have been having a blast!

It's really good. I bought this without knowing much about it. Just looked cool on the store page, so I went for it. I'm super pleasantly surprised. It's basically the same as "They Are Billions," but medeval. I love these kinds of base-building wave defense RTS games; this is one of the better ones I've played. Great graphics; it runs super well, even with 25,000 enemies attacking all at once (thats the maximum number). It has a lot of content; there's a full campaign, endless modes, sandbox mode, etc. Sandbox is quite fun; you can set up the exact conditions you want to play with: map size, type, enemy variety, cheats, and on and on. If you like RTS base-building games, get this; it's great. If you like games where you need to defend against waves, get this; it's great. Just get it. It's great. :)
great base building wave defence game with some neat campaign missions to keep things interesting.

This game offers a challenge for players familiar with RTS games. However, has a rather steep learning curve and even the easiest difficulty may prove to be difficult for newer players of this genre. I am hopeful that over time this game can be balanced and tweaked difficulty wise so that more people can enjoy it. Aside from difficulty, gameplay is fun and definitely worth a try!

This is my first RTS in a long while and I am hooked. So far I have only been doing campaign missions (there are also challenge, sandbox and endless modes). The missions are long (~4h) and have branching paths and maps are randomly generated so there is high replay value. I think I won't finish my first campaign run at least until I am 80 hours in. Even though the game markets itself primary as a tower defense survive the hordes type game, there are objectives that force you to be the attacker while also still keeping the hordes in check (depending on the game mode ofc) and i really like those gameplay shakeups. Like having a boss mob with a high pool of health to kill (don't skip the concert :)). The story doesn't take itself too seriously, but still manages to be engaging and good fun. The only gripe I have is that I am unsure what the difficulty settings affect (only enemy spawn rates? maybe also map generation?). The campaign also ramps up difficulty by default the more you progress but some general tooltip that explains each difficulty mode changes would be nice. So far I gathered that it affects the number of objectives to complete later campaign missions, the size of the hordes and your starting resources/army. I will stick to the medium difficulty going forward I guess. If you are on the fence, I suggest giving it a try. So far this is a 9/10 for me and RTS type games don't usually click for me. EDIT: typos...

This game has a lot of potential, but during early access, I gave up in the hopes that the crushing difficulty would get easier once they hit retail. Nothing of the sort, after many more hours struggling in the easiest settings, I have thrown in the towel on the ship-building level. I understand that the expectation is that you will pause often to micromanage every facet of your settlement, but it's just too much to keep my interest. It's more like level after level of work than actual game-playing. Not a casual game by any stretch of the imagination, even on the easiest settings. A shame, because the overall concept seems fun. If only the creators actually *allowed* us to have fun with it.
Very good system of organization and military chaos. I love watching them fly when the trebuchet hits

Very high quality game in terms of base building/management and has a very tricky balance of economy vs military as the hordes become more and more terrifying wave after wave. Anyone giving this game a bad review becauase of the difficulty are just looking for the easy way out and dont understand that your not meant to win first time everytime learning from your mistakes and trying again is half the fun in this game GREAT WORK DEVS HOPE YOU DO SIMILAR WORK ON ADD EXPASIONS IN THE FUTURE

Great fun. Campaign has good diversity of mission goals and formats. It's not all just build up your base and defend. Some are more offensive, another where you guard a moving caravan. I'm enjoying the campaign a lot. It has points early on where you can choose a side. I think there are three available in the game currently(including the king). There are cut scenes between missions that have humor that I enjoy, but others might find annoying. The game also has challenge modes and endless maps.

I was pleasantly surprised with this game, i had no expectations and hadnt seen clips of it beforehand. Started off my campaign and as I love suffering I chose "ultra-hardcore" as my difficulty to commit too (difficulty 3 of 5, not too crazy). Game does a fair enough job explaining how to play until it all of sudden on mission 4 you find yourself in the deep end which was a lot of fun but did require a reload. JUST as i started thinking it may be a bit to shallow for my taste, the next mission had a whole set of new perimeters, units, and game play! Its really cool that the game gives you choices that totally change your campaign experience and allow for a fair amount of replayability, and I really look forward to what the devs add next! Its not that often where modern games force you to figure stuff out on the fly and cause you to have to use actual STRATEGY to win, but this game is tough enough to make you work for it! *TIPS - even the campaign is on randomly generated maps so feel free to restart missions if you find yourself off pace and getting overwhelmed, it'll feel like a new attempt without cheesily letting you know too much about the map to make it easy. EASILY worth $30, maybe more and looking forward to new playable factions in the future!
Its fun and challenging, the campaign is build so you have to (in a sens) restart your progress and build your fortress again. Just like in the old days with stronghold games.

You know what I like? When I have an upgraded wall with several upgraded towers with crossbowmen and catapults behind it, and then some enemies demolish my walls and start destroying my city, cause my walls completely block friendly projectiles from passing. That's what I like. Actually, I fucking LOVE it.

By now, this game was definitely worth its cost for me :) Supported in Early Access, enjoyed the challenge missions and dabbled a little into endless mode before release. It took some time to get used to the amount of scaling and micromanagement needed in DINAO. The campaign is enjoyable, has some twists and turns and a variety of paths with different missions depending on your decisions. So far the missions are pretty balanced IF you have some experience in DINAO. I am having a very good time with this game! I saw a lot of people getting stuck on a difficulty spike at the 4th mission, mostly due to slow progress in the early game (Day 1-10) which apparently got pretty frustrating. Looking back I agree that there could've been more easing in or directly teaching the necessity to scale properly. Overproduction and rapid population growth are key in DINAO.
its quite good.

Worth a purchase when its on sale. It's a fun They Are Billions clone. I disagree with the difficulty complaints of some other reviewers. I've been playing on Ultra Hardcore and it's a challenge but doable. I recommend that setting for anyone who enjoyed TAB. It's not super polished which is why it's a sale game. Cutscenes are incredibly slow and boring with barely any animation, Building jingles are all pretty annoying, and I suspect there might be some light asset flipping going on here. I haven't run into any bugs though and the game runs butter smooth on a 4060! There are things I can nitpick about it but if you like RTS or are a fan of TAB, it's definitely worth a play through. 7/10

This game isn't a true wave defending game such as cataclismo it leans a lot closer to a rts like starcraft. After every few days a wave of enemies will come and attack your base and the waves get harder and harder the more days that pass. This wave defending mechanic happens passively along side the main campaign objective so there is some urgency built in. While this is an interesting take on the rts genre it does come with some frustrating moments.

the best thing i can say about DINO is that its consistently fun to fail. It's always on you to be better and the tools are at your disposal to do it. It can feel overwhelming and unfair at times - but that spurred me on to get better and more efficient, making the feeling of accomplishment genuine and satisfying as hell! the city building mechanics/options are genuinely great in their own right - stacked on top of a tower defense design that elevates everything to a whole other level. after 20+ hours i havent even experienced of those Lord of the Rings style mega-battles - because im still trying to protect my base from utter implosion from smaller waves coming from all sides. those large battles were the reason i was so intrigued by the game to start with. So the fact that im still yet to even reach them is just another reason to keep playing and see just how good I can get. hard recommend. original review at around the 8 hr mark: This game is wildly underrated. A perfect fusion of city building, action RTS and tower defense. Absolutely fantastic.

Well made and thought out, excited to complete the game as well. Hoping I don't have to run through every single level again to in order to see the alternate endings, hoping I can just pick up at the branching campaign points. Gameplay and economy system on point, seems scaling is working well as well.
Love this game, the blend of C&C like mechanics with Tower Defense just kicks it out of the park. Looking forward to many DLCs and expansions!

I hate to say it but I cannot recammend this game, even though I'd love to as a fan of base builders. The game is just too tedious. It takes forever to gather resources, making base building slow and cumbersome; all the while you're being attacked by stronger and stronger waves. Some mission goals for resources are insanely high as well. Upgrading townhall from level 1-2 takes 150 wood. From 2-3 takes 600, in addition to stone, iron and money. The timing on cutscenes is also really bad, to the point were I just started skipping all of them, even though there is come good comedy. Imagine you're having a conversation with someone but they only speak one sentence every 4-5 seconds but maintain eye contact with you the whole time. The game's pacing needs serious work and now that it's 1.0 I doubt it will improve. If you're a huge fan or wave games or base builders *maybe* give it a try, if it's on sale. If you're on the fence, don't waste your money. Good concept, poor execution.

As a huge fan of "They are Billions" this game fixes most of the major gripes I had with that game. Mainly: - one lone zombie that's very hard to see won't wreck your entire game - No lame/repetitive single hero control missions with item hunting. - Audio is far less annoying - The PTSD inducing existential dread is far cumbersome. Some negatives I would love the devs to address: - Kiting enemies still works extremely well but is just annoying and time consuming to do. even more so since there is no shift-click pathing option. I wish kiting enemies wasn't helpful and part of the core harder difficulty gameplay. - I wish the military units were better at auto picking up nearby items/drops on the map. Again, just really annoying have to take one unit and tell them to go pick up the thing again and again. I swear 1/10 clicks I either click right next to the thing and find the guy just standing there touching the item but they didn't pick it up.

Fast paced game, you can't chill with this one. Love the constant pressure - you lapse, you lose. Not for those who want a chill city builder (maybe on the lowest difficulty?). Love this game, big hordes, epic battles, against all odds type scenarios. Get it, play it, story or challenge mode. I got this in early access and have come back for more on release of 1.0. Still enjoying it, so clearly they have a good formula. Looking forward to the success of this game.

Crazy good game with amazing dark humour. I enjoyed every single cutscene in the campaign. I am not going to waste any time praising those epic moments when your walls shield you from thousands of enemies while you're shelling them from towers with trebuchets, making them ragdoll all over the place... You've seen them in pretty much every promotional video, and they are exactly as epic and fun as they looked. As for the negatives, it is true what people are saying - once you "figure the game out", you will repeat the same steps in pretty much every single mission. Not that I mind, I find the gameplay loop very enjoyable. Also, I think the game could use some endgame goal, some gameender that you can slowly build towards. Right now it's pretty easy to rush the strongest units and that's it... Either way, [b] highly [/b] recommended.

I've been playing on the lowest difficulty as some reviews noted there is a sharp difficulty jump in mission 4. I'm unclear what people meant by this as I did not seem to notice this. Perhaps they are very new to strategy games or paid no attention to the tutorial or a combination of the two. It seems to ramp up at a pretty predictable pace as far as I could tell. I wanted a low-frustration and enjoyable "Turtle" experience as that was always *My* preferred play style in any RTS title, though none really support or encourage that. This scratches that itch for me and I've enjoyed it quite a bit so far.

Overall a really fun and entertaining game. I really like the Warcraft 3 influences on the campaign. Just wish the game had more 'character', so much of RTSes are the unique look and sounds of characters and units and I think this game lacks that. This game is a lot of fun, but very difficult. I am playing through the campaign right now, and must say, I am having a lot of fun. The missions, so far, are varied. Most of the missions are either 10 minutes, or 2 hours, depending on what the goal is. If you fail a mission, the map will change. Also, you can change the difficulty once you fail or restart a mission. From what I can tell, there is a story and you have a choice to make in the second mission. This choice will dictate who you are fighting and how difficult the game will be. I chose the option that the game told me would be harder, and so far... it is harder. A lot harder. Have fun, and remember... Diplomacy is NOT an option!

This game reminds me of when I was younger and played age of mythology. It doesn't take its self too seriously. It has quirky powers you can use like a death lazer. The game proves to be somewhat difficult with 5/6 levels to choose from for difficulty. Enemy unit types seem pretty varied, and scale with the waves as they come, getting harder and harder forcing you to keep upgrading and adapting. The map is littered with eneimes who tend to guard resources you can get to boost your progress, along with soul gems needed to cast spells. Awesome "Stronghold" style game. If you liked those original castle sims then this is for you. A fun campaign with selectable levels of difficulty (Easy to Dark Souls) depending on the mood you're in.

I just started playing this game, and I can already say that this is one of the most fun RTS games I've ever played. The campaign is fun, challenging, and designed quite well. Unlike most games in the genre, there is not a max troop count. This allows you to build massive armies as long as you have enough housing for them. The battles you will face are awesome to watch as both sides fight to the death by any means necessary. The only downside to the game would be small bugs and lack of control over units. There will be situations where you want your soldiers to move to a certain location or fight a certain enemy, and they kinda get lost/disobey. Besides these issues, this game is one heck of a blast.
Love Tower Defence and Base Building. Great Game!

Finally beat the Campaign doing all King path and I have to say, the difficulty settings need adjustments. Feels weird to have 5 options and the top 2 easy options are really hard to pull off for a lot of people. For example, the other faction will have the ability to spawn 40 guys (top tier) ever 50 seconds on the final king path missions and have to cheese the fight to win. This is not good design at all. To expand, it feels like they did a great job of your units for defense but fail to make your units good for Offense which you need on a lot of missions. I will still recommend the game for the sandbox and other stuff but the campaign is a bit crazy and hard to enjoy if you pick the easier options. Feels like they wanted to make a dark souls RTS base defense story which does not work well. They also need to make enjoying all paths easier. Currently you should save or load auto saves at each choice path. Not a great way to enjoy all the effort and work the team put into missions and cut-scenes.

I picked this up 5 days ago and beat the campaign on medium difficulty ("Ultra Hardcore") tonight. As an avid RTS gamer in my 30s, who gravitates towards playing every game at the highest difficulty, I'm glad I read some posts on the Reddit first and stuck to medium. Man, it was hard. My favorite thing about this game is how it constantly challenges your expectations. Much higher difficulty than your average game. Really off-putting pacing in the cut scenes, just for fun. Unique art style, interesting take on translations, and little eccentricities everywhere like never showing the lord's face (going so far as to have a blurred face texture on his in-game unit). The game has a lot of character. I'd compare it most closely to They Are Billions, but it plays quite differently. Gone is the annoying challenge of constantly inching your units forward to clear the map, every single map. You might have to do it once or twice, but each mission has different challenges - some are focused on the waves, some are focused on clearing spawners, some are focused on assaulting a fortified position, some have just a single very difficult final wave. It was interesting to need to adapt each time. My biggest complaint about the game is simply the pathfinding AI - units tend to clump up instead of spreading evenly. It's especially annoying with your own units, because it makes them much less effective in combat without micro. But it also feels a little weird that the AI will happily beat on a 5 layer wall directly in front of them instead of just walking around. But to be honest, that's a pretty small complaint given the scope of this game. It's overall quite polished. I really enjoyed my play-through and am looking forward to coming back at a later date to try it again on the hardest difficulty.

this is a great game that i stumbled across, It fills the gap i always wanted in AoE 2 that this game supplies perfectly in its core mechanics with endless waves to fend off! The campaign is super fun and easy to play, the choices you make in it feel meaningful and impactful with as you play threw. Some things i would love to see in future updates would be things like ladder enemy's or other units that circumvent walls in different ways or maybe even the ability to dig trenches or moats. I do think it dose need a few more ''bits and bobs" for late game as things like endless mode have you max tier rather quickly, which is great for keeping the game simple and for shorter rounds but, would love something shiny in later endless mode games like special units or buildings. I also would love to see visual representation of damage to walls and buildings to see them barely standing at the end of the wave or crumble to dust as you get swarmed. Multiplayer would also be fun. i think verses or co-op would bring whole new layers of fun to an already great game. highly recommend this game, it is both fun easy to learn but puts up a great challenge and has excellent pick up and put down capability.

The art uses a simplistic style that allows it to show a large scale and unique design to convey an interesting, lighthearted atmosphere. The tower defense aspect coupled with the freedom of how, where, and what you build (limited by a smart progression system) makes for a very exciting gameplay format I personally enjoy in many strategy games. My personal favorite aspect aside from the varied unit designs in the armies and the the expansive cities is the fun cutscenes between campaign levels that are very humorous and uniquely written.

Even though the engine, design and sound effects are nice, the gameplay itself isn't that good. Combining city builder with rts mechanics on top of tower defence layer and also having story events on top of that sounds cool, but without granular balancing it would basically make this game something like "pause for 10 minutes to give orders and build, then play 4x-speed for 1 minute, then repeat, increasing time in pause to micromanage as the city and army are growing". And this is exactly what's wrong with this game, even on the easiest difficulty, as other comments might say. So, "yes" for hellish micromanagement enjoyers, but in general - nope.

I have a genuine love and appreciation for an RTS. I gave this one more than enough of my time. The campaign is genuinely beyond unbalanced. I get that it needs to be hard and enjoyable, and it is fun. However, having to constantly save scum and constantly restart in order to get a favorable starting position isn't fun. You're constantly punished for playing the game. No matter what strategy or how quickly you secure a position, the next wave will always be harder to deal with than you are ready for. In the 8th mission set on the campaign I have restarted probably 30 times in an attempt to get a favorable starting position and to defend against the next wave. It has not been enough. It is impossible. Mind that I have been playing on the easiest difficulty, and I am no slouch with an RTS. Please adjust enemy health/unit damage. It shouldn't take 3 catapult balls to kill the second from weakest enemy soldier. It shouldn't take 5+ arrows for an archer to kill the second from weakest soldier. Especially when each wave has dozens to hundreds of them. Houses should be able to hold more people as well. Its all around too constricting while demanding the impossible.
A negative review is not an option

The campaign is too hard, even on easy. I'm about 10 missions in, and it's a struggle. You don't get that nice satisfaction of building up an economy and then steamrolling the opponent. It's more of a fight against time, you know that if you take your time building up you'll get taken out. Clearly this works for some people, but, ultimately, with all the reloads / replays, I'm not enjoying it as much. On top of that, like with most RTSs you have to micro your forces, deal with broken pathfinding, and so on. Just add an actual easy option to the game, or I don't know, settings or something. Also, don't make me micro units. If a unit is about to die, it's fine for it to fall back behind its buddies without me having to click everywhere. Maybe add that as an option?

DINAO is a game that I have been extremely impressed by in the time I have played it. It is filled to the brim with passion and inspiration, while being smooth running and nice looking. From the little sound cues you get when clicking on buildings, to the different personalities of soldier classes, and the charming art design this team has really separated themselves from just another [insert RTS classic] clone. While taking inspiration from its predecessors, it borrows their best elements and builds upon them tremendously. The city building feels close to perfect for a game like this. My favorite part of games of AoE was building bases and just trying to survive while attacked on all sides and this is pretty much my dream in that regard. Everything feels well calculated to provide enough depth to building and defense without becoming too overwhelming for a game that is as much an RTS as a building game. For future development I would love to maybe see a little more depth to the building system, as it stands right now it is great just not perfect in my opinion. Perhaps adding more depth to architecture and such will be the domain of modders? I am excited for the future of this game!

First off, I want to say this game is challenging and fun and I would recommend it, BUT the campaign in its current state is not balanced well to the point that it ruins the experience. I had 30+ hours in the pre 1.0 release so I understood the games mechanics going into the campaign, but I'm at a point (about half way through) where I cannot progress, despite being on the easiest difficulty, as there is not enough time to extract resources so that you can build good defenses. This isn't a problem with just the level I'm currently on either. This has been a reoccurring theme where you have to scramble to set up enough resource buildings so you can build your army large enough to defeat enemy waves that attack from random directions. If you don't get enough resources in time, then you can't build good buildings, and then can't build good armies, and then game will crush you with endless waves of enemies that get larger even if you're struggling to rebuild from the last wave. It's very frustrating when you put hours into building a great city, when it only takes a few small groups of weak enemies, attacking from many different directions, to destroy enough of your buildings so that your resources are drained and are defenseless against the next enemy wave. I really wish I could give a positive review because a lot of effort has been put into this game and at times it is fun to play, but the game is a sweatfest even at the easiest difficulty. I will change my review if the game and balancing is updated, and I really hope it is because the potential to have a really fun experience is there but needs work.

Amazing mix of RTS and tower-defense - engaging in its difficulty in that it makes you actively learn how to play and does not pull any punches in its difficulty curve. The expectation of enemy waves and the dynamics of where / how enemies choose to attack keep each moment of each game engaging, aided by the use of procedurally generated maps and a magic system a la Stronghold Crusader Extreme. AoE fans would feel some familiarity with some elements of the game, with some much-needed originality thrown in to keep things fresh and exciting.

Currently it is a 6/10 or maybe a 7/10 if you really are really into this niche Also be fairly warned that the game's humor is very odd, which is to say that the mobs are not only aware they are mobs, they also mock the game design and 4th wall constantly, Not taking itself seriously can be good in moderation, but becomes timesome when it happens 100% of the time Bit of a theme for the game really, it has no absolutely idea when to stop or focus on its better parts.

An absolutely amazing game that scratches an itch I didn't know I had! I used to love tower defense games as a kid and playing this brings back all those good memories. My one big problem with this game, and the reason I've stopped playing it completely is the difficulty curve. The first 3 missions are a breeze and then you hit the 4th (Off We Go My Lord)... There is a constant wave of enemies spawning from the South every minute or so, on top of the regular waves every few in game days, on top of needing to build 4 expensive ships, ON TOP OF having to build an army of almost 100 tier 2+ soldiers... And this is all on only the 2nd difficulty :O This has made it so I can't experience the rest of the campaign which is a real shame. I understand the devs recently patched this mission to be easier on all difficulties but it's still unreasonable to the point I can't even play.

for more than 20 years ive been a fan of RTS/base building/ survival games. this game checks a lot of boxes, BUT it is truly un balanced and needs some major work. the issue with these new age RTS/Base Building games is its GO GO GO HURRY UP and this does that a bit, its less about building an army and building up your city/castle and more about "hurry up can you handle this wave and repair before the next one". in sandbox mode it is a very fun game but alot of times even with extra resources you tend to run out of food unless you can find a large plot of land you can protect to drop 7 or 8 farms on. This is just a very quick review. the games Fun, The games time consuming(good thing), the game needs serious balancing. over all for me as is its 7/10. i hope they keep working on it and turn it into what it can be which is a very VERY good game

Game balance is just way off. Horribly finite resources make building any sort of capable defenses tedious and a considerable struggle. Level 4 was certainly difficult but the levels thereafter are even worse, even after the update. Honestly, the game just isn't fun and needs to be re-balanced, regardless of what the dev might say. My suggestions: - Improve missile AI to better engage targets. Right now, you could have 100 archers shooting at the same enemy and all of the arrows aren't connecting because of the weird positioning. A tower's position along a wall shouldn't lose an entire run because you realized too late all of your arrows will just miss. Is there any real reason for arrow collision other than to frustrate the player? - Resource nodes could use a significant bump. I understand wanting the player to expand to gain resources, but the amount of resources given means you cannot adequately defend any new positions taken. The gold mechanic required to tech up just exacerbates this issue. At the present, I can see resource nodes being bumped by at least 30% and the game still being very difficult. - If resource nodes aren't adjusted, then the gold mechanic is too brutal. Introducing a way to generate gold passively either through a new tax building or node could help the situation and give players a chance to get their economy going before getting overwhelmed. At present, a player is required to dump insane amounts of resources into the market just to get to tier 3, then not be able to afford anything tier 3 has to offer before all of the nodes nearby are dry. - I would say lessening the amount of enemy units should be the last option for balancing, considering the theme of the game. The player should just be given more tools and resources to handle the enemies presented. Buffing player units would be a better solution. Either expand the research upgrades each unit can receive, or perhaps introduce a veterancy system for units to be able to better handle the enemies that they are thrown against, which could buff units based on kills. The fact you could probably implement all of these suggestions and the game would *still* be difficult is a testament to how difficult the game is in its current state.

I really want to like this game. The fact that even after dropping to the lowest difficulty, I still feel extremely time-gated and advancing slower than required to keep up with the AI has turned the fun into frustration. There needs to be some balancing adjustments done on the difficulty levels. Also, having a line of enemies coming at you as a single wave warning alert only to then have them split as 3-4 paths without any warning is rather annoying and has caused me to reload saves multiple times once I know where they are going to come from. Honestly it's just been easier to start save scumming and rushing down the objective which is not really fun nor strategic.

Absolutely amazing game. I love RTS games and this one is now one of my all time favorites. Its smooth, its clean, and its so so hard I want to pull my hair out it can be so difficult. Nothing to say but buy it if you have any interest in RTS games. Now some recommendations for the producers to make it even better. 1: add some new spells. Maybe pick and choose one while upgrading town hall. 2: more variety of maps. Love the maps but some more variety would be fun. More mountainous maps, river maps, etc. 3: MULTIPLAYER. I know this is a long shot but if you could do multiplayer to face opponents that would be so much fun. Love the game so much and already addicted. Looking forward to the future of the game.

I've been looking for a spiritual successor for They Are Billions for years. For me, this is it! Many things are similar but with an added twist or improvement. Just to mention a few of the things that I really liked: - You can put archers on the walls - Opening the gates can let enemies pass through Resource Management is very well thought out and quite deep: - upkeep + finite resources + transportation from source to storage + sickness/burial of dead troops Just a few suggestions that can maybe make it more realistic: - zombies (yes, zombies!) will always attack you even though they spawned beside enemy camps - random hordes / scouts (enemies in the map just stay in their camps - although I've only played a few levels in the game, this might be true for advanced levels) Overall, having a blast playing this game. Only playing the campaign for now. Cutscenes are light vs the serious tone of They Are Billions. 10/10 for me!

I don't hate the starvation aspect of the bug maps but i'm not sure how you're supposed to raise a big enough army to fight the generals and gods that spawn. My solution was to just cheese it with healers and one melee guy but that's just not fun. The god has an aoe which kills all your dudes so you rely on healers to heal one melee dude. That's not a terrible situation but it's boring and you basically 3x speed until the day is over. Fighting the nightmare generals is the exact same fight because they too kill all your melee guys with an aoe so it's another boring fight of kiting one troop around while it gets ranged to death.

This game is hard. Take the difficulty levels literally! The resource management element is much more important than many other civ managements, and I found even playing on easy mode to be a rough ride. You constantly need more wood, but if you dont save resources then you wont have upgrades. Yet if you dont spend them then you run out of resource income, and then you need more for ships, upgrades, troops! It's a crazy balancing act but a ton of fun and exactly what I've been looking for. Superb. An Age of Empires style casual RTS with tons of content, cute, funny cutscenes and very well implemented base building. Game needs huge QoL. I really enjoy it, but until they implement more QoL I will leave this review negative. Spoilers ahead. 1. Needs a better way to make units move without attacking. Searched through the options and the only way is to go R, CLICK, R, CLICK or whatever button you choose. Can basically not kite around enemy camps without pausing the game to actually move decently every half a second or so. 2. Units need an Idle option where they can stand there without attacking. If i have any unit literally anywhere and an enemy walks into their line of sight, the unit WILL attack. If it's a ranged unit it will even attack on Hold. What's the point of formations and stuff when your Units don't really care? 3. Better visibility on lone enemies. One or two enemies may not even light up red. I had a Walking corpse destroy my Townhall while I was busy bombing Ozzy and couldn't find the source of destruction even after reloading. Turns out that somehow a walking corpse turned on his cheats and walked between two builders huts up against my castle.

It ticks all the right boxes in all the right ways. Its challenging, but rewarding, even on lower difficulty consideration and planning are key. 8/10. There are some frustrations about the way you are forced to play, even on the lowest difficulty. "Challenge accepted" is my current default, but testing it, even on "walk in the park" you are still forced to play aggressively expansionist due to resources both food/wood/stone etc. all being mined out relatively quickly, this means, you cannot really turtle or fortify easily, nor take your sweet time, as without expanding you simply cannot field the army needed to deal with either quest items or the later waves. Farms for example, take up way too much space which makes them hard to use early, and if you do, likely you will be ripping up trees, which are also a finite resource. All of the above will get better with balance changes i am sure, and all the core elements are there to make this an amazing experience.

I like the bit I played but feel like the game kinda doesn't know what it wants to be, city builder? colony management? tower defence? main thing is that it does non of them well but all kinda meh. I liked building the walls of the city and thinking how i'd defend it but when the enemies came your archers just shoot through stuff and your footmen are just really good compared to the npc (this was the very begining so maybe later it's harder) plus the combat is kinda weird like I'd click my guys to fight but half of them would just stand around while the other half actually fought or they'd ignore the enemies and just attack a hut instead. Building the city was nice it looks nice and its really easy but it does lack in depth and there's no real point in building with any order and you can't place stuff right next to each other or the townfolk would get stuck in the building meaning your city takes up way more room than you think you need. Why have a tech tree/research system? seems kinda pointless, instead just give me better stuff as I upgrade my keep, just seems like something they added because other games have it, doesn't add anything other than an annoying thing I have to check every 2 minutes which add kinda pointless upgrades. The management aspect is really basic, your guys eat food you just gotta have enough each day kinda thing which you get by placing a fishing hut etc.. It's simple and not worth noting for the most part its just really basic. I do think adding the power to shoot a laser from the sky or spawn some guys from hell is also a pointless thing and they're really op,.I do think this game could of focused on actually making good defences a more important thing rather than just lasing every enemy from orbit just seems like a kinda missed chance. Overall I refunded this game and will keep tabs on it for the future as I think it could be pretty good given some time to stew and respond to feedback :)

This is a really great spiritual successor to They Are Billions. The campaign is an improvement on just proc-gen endless modes, but I'd say with some significant missed opportunities. The story/writing in this game wants to be funny, but it landed pretty flat for me.

I enjoy this game for a number of reasons and love many of the mechanics. However... the absolutely merciless ramp up of the difficulty in the campaign on the 4th mission is insane. I've learned a few things and started to progress a little bit farther but still haven't completed it, even after dropping the difficulty down to the lowest setting. I always get to a certain point where it just seems impossible to fend off the constant waves of enemies from the south while also dealing with the regular hordes of enemies that come less frequently and doing the objectives at the same time. I end up using all of my resources on the first things I mentioned and have nothing left to trade in at an insanely bad exchange rate for gold so that I can build the troops needed to put on the ships. I begin to run out of resources in safe areas and have to build work sites that inevitably get destroyed when the next large wave comes. The time in between waves seems like just enough to recover from the previous one, only to get rewarded with a fresh wave of enemies. I feel like this would be a whole lot better without the constant wave from the south. Then I could actually focus on the other mechanics. I really wanted to like this game, then it moved into my "spite finish" category, and now I can't be bothered. The game is missing some combination of 3-4 somethings. Playing on the hardest difficulty with no real problems other than I just don't want to play the game anymore. 1- Every game is the same. No meta progression, early on I stumbled onto the best way to power up my economy and I can't find a valid reason to play differently. 2- Upgrades are bland, boring, uninteresting. I take the same ones every game, as they fall into 'mandatory' or 'useless' categories 3- Siege weapons is where the game turns into a beating. Your siege weapons take forever to take out towers, theirs are exceedingly hard to get to - and the only danger their army will ever present. 4- Bullet sponge (but that might just be a difficulty thing, could be an active decision) but with how clunky melee is you're relegated to mass backline. Which is okay, but forces a unit composition. 5- Unit cost. Again, this is for harder difficulties, but I can't bring myself to buy spearmen when axemen have better upgrades and are way cheaper to produce - even with their situational anti-cavalry status. Maybe it's a unit diversity issue too? Maybe it's someone else's cup of tea, but as an RTS player who likes games in the genre this entirely missed the mark for me.

This is supposed to be a game where you defend against massive hoards of enemies, but somehow there's a lot of base building/management that distract you from the actual fun stuff. You have to build houses to increase your population limit building food production requires workers which count toward your population limit you can also build house for more "builders" which are required to actually build your buildings food resources deplete so you have to move your building and production from time to time however there are roaming enemies which makes the above difficult enemies can also attack from any direction so you have to consider that when expanding your base you have limited food and material storage, so you have to build storage buildings there is a tech tree to complete I would say all this is just too much distraction from what I actually want to be doing in this game. All these things are not bad to have in a city building/survival game but this is not that, this is an RTS and having to consider things like food just gets in the way of fun.

This game is extremely fun, you can sink hours upon hours into the campaign however there are a 3 things I would like the devs to address for the campaign in particular 1 level pacing: the levels in DiNaO can vary wildly in difficulty with some levels being especially difficult to complete even in the easist difficulty, some of the late levels feel outright impossible with basically everything needing to go your way in order to even have a shot of winning. 2 resource collection: resources in this game can be wildly inconsistent when it comes to their generation, because DiNaO has a constantly regenerating map (U will never play the same map) resource spawns can either make or break your campaign level. some games you get a good map with good cliff location, stone and iron deposites with a handful of infinte spawns within and easy and safe distance to gather. other times you find 90% of your stone and iorn sitting on the exterior side of cliffs making it incredibly difficult to secure starving you of resources and ruining your game. 3 Waves and enemies: this game in incredibly ruthless in how its enemies attack, some times you have ample and opportune times to focus on your economy, working on getting some progress done between enemy attacks, other levels most notably the first level u encounter crabs you simply have no time to actually build up or recover from attacks as the attack waves just blast through you too often to set up and effective defence and economy. once your behind you might as well restart as recovering is insanely difficult. This is just my experience from just the campaign on the easiest difficultly, god forbid you try doing this on anything more difficult that hard.

I changed my review from positive to negative after I realized the game mechanics is emphasizing too much on rushing you. It is fun spending time with the colony, expanding its population, make a thriving economy, set up defenses and go exploring. The problem is, the game doesnt allow you to enjoy those things. Even on the lowest difficulty level you will face rapidly increasingly powerful hordes until you die, no matter what. Unless you rush to finish your objective before that happen. It is very frustrating to play for a solid hour, just to find that the enemy has scaled up so much that the huge spike in difficulty decimates your whole colony without you being able to do anything about it. It is like you really love ice cream, and while enjoying it someone puts a gun to your head and tell you to push it down your throat in ten seconds or die. Technically you ate an enjoyable ice cream, but like in this game the experience is ruined by the aggressive rushing mechanics. Maybe some people like games with a countdown timer type of level design, but I really dont. I could beat the levels once I realized rushing is the key, but then I did not enjoy the game much. Needs a game mode / level that doesnt scale the attacks so rapidly, so you can enjoy it without being rushed and frustrated. People who like a countdown timer type gameplay and pressure can of course just choose the higher difficulty levels. Will change the review if this is addressed.

Alright, here’s how it went the first time I played Diplomacy is Not an Option. I jump in thinking, “Great, bit of strategy, build a castle, defend it, maybe even have time to enjoy a nice medieval sunset.” But nope. First wave of enemies shows up before I’ve even put the foundations down. It’s like trying to build a sandcastle while a toddler stomps all over it. You barely get a breather. The pace is insane. They should call it Diplomacy is Definitely Not an Option Because You're Too Busy Panicking. I’m sitting there thinking, "Maybe I’ve done something wrong. Am I missing something? Is there a setting for people who actually want to build a castle before the game turns into medieval Doom?" Nope, not in the campaign. Even on easy mode, it's relentless. I’m sweating. I’m shouting at my screen. It’s madness. And the thing is, I love strategy games! But this? This feels like they took the stress of real-time strategy and cranked it up to ‘Oh god, why did I do this to myself?’ Then, miracle of miracles, I find out about the sandbox and endless modes. Turns out, if you want a more relaxed experience—where you can actually, you know, build your bloody castle before the world falls apart—they’ve got you covered. Much better. You can chill out a bit, take your time, not feel like you’re constantly under siege. But seriously, the campaign? Avoid if you don’t fancy having a heart attack at your desk.
You can't complete the third campaign even at the easiest difficulty.

Okay, for a game that contains so far as I can tell not a single novel gameplay element, this is remarkably engaging and well-designed. Some games are good because they innovate and some are good because they present familiar concepts in an engaging and well-executed way. The "chunky" aesthetics are cute. Recommend if you like base builders, base defenders, or Dungeon Keeper.
