Update 26/10/24 - Patch was released to rebalance mission 4 in particular and it was markedly more aligned with the difficulty curve you might expect. I would even say it was enjoyable. Changing review to "recommended" and a shout out to the dev for seeing the error of their initial approach and LISTENING to the playerbase - thank you! Had this on my wishlist for much of its beta time. Bought it once it launched and was really happy with it, but the ramp up around mission 3 / 4 is ridiculous. I want to like this, and as a fan of They are Billions, I was so sure this would fit the bill. Alas, not right now. Might change my review if the dev balances the game a bit, but as others have said, it seems the dev is more interested in telling players to "git gud" as opposed to fixing their poor work. Seems kinda counter intuitive to make a game thats unbalanced, which then no ones buys because its unbalanced, but then you dont fix it because for them, its fine?

edit: I can't recommend this until they do something about the difficulty. It's a fun game but, my God, they need to do something about the cutscenes. They're too slow and just seem to be vehicles for (bland) jokes instead of any kind of story or narrative? That's not to say they're not entertaining, but they're like five minutes long and they feel even longer. They're a real blemish on the game. That said, I'm enjoying the game play a lot, even if it's not perfect. It'd be nice if there were a few QOL things implemented, such as reminding the player that they're not researching anything, and maybe even allowing you to auto-rebuild buildings. edit: There are some extreme spikes in difficulty, and even as an RTS veteran playing on the *lowest difficulty setting*, some of the missions require you to play perfectly with aggressive, expansionist play and pinpoint timings. This is the biggest mark against the game, I think.

I Have always loved Tower defense games, all the way back to FieldRunners on IOS. Some things to note for some balancing if a dev sees this: I may suck to the point I have to beat the campaign on "walk in the park", but in the beginning of the match, the waves are far too frequent for the amount of enemies that spawn in them, and the enemy bases are far too close in order to establish any sort of castle without them destroying a few buildings in the first day. Also, It may just be a skill issue, but my whole strategy has been hundreds of crossbowmen and the 30 troop soul knight regiment to clear anything on the map. This is just preference, but it seems like the only way to win any of the matches without going broke from training new troops everytime a clash happens. All in all, great job so far, I cant wait to finish the campaign, and great work!

At first I thought the people complaining about the difficulty spike in the 4th mission, were just not figuring out the game... But once I hit it, and replayed it three times, each time trying something new, I understand. While I am sure I'll get it, the park-walk of the first three missions makes the 4th unnecessarily brutal. And rather than ease the player base into things a little slower and retool the difficulty. The devs have pretty much flipped everyone complaining the finger and said, GET GUD NUB. Seriously. It's such a massive change in tactics and timings that MOST players will struggle enough to get angry... And that's on easy mode. While that is certainly their prerogative, it is hardly conducive to creating good will, nor encouraging. So, I am adding my disapproval, in the form of an official complaint/review. Since the forums won't do it, maybe dropping the review score will. There is no need to spike the difficulty so insanely, so quickly. None what so ever. Let alone blame the players for not figuring it out quick enough, rather than adjust timings and give helpful advice.

This is probably one of the better RTS games in my opinion. It reminds me of older ones from the 90s where difficulty is something that you had to overcome rather than it be handed to you. I read reviews like Alitari and those types of negative reviews are obvious of someone who played the first two levels and then came here to leave a snarky review talking about how they didn't like it because of things they never played long enough to find. People such as Alitari and others are used to games that hand you the answers. This is a game where you learn to get good on each map and learn different ways to get good. I spent the entire day on a singular level until I finally learned the way to handle it. The game gives you enough tools to handle it, you just have to learn how to use it. Is the game perfect? No but its better than a lot of AAA games that come out. Give the game a shot and remember that this game is not a friendly "I want to be handed things because I don't want to get good". This game is like "They are Billions" where you find ways to survive and adapt and overcome. Try it out! But don't listen to people who whine because it is too hard. Those people are the same type who played Dark Souls and cried because it didn't have an easy mode.

I have played this game in EA, and boy has it delivered on release. I am not even half way through the campaign, but it's just astonishing. Also, for me, unit balance was very important. During EA melee units were just a source of problems, spreading disease. Now they actually make sense, because of how fast they regen, AND the attacking waves include archers, who prefer focusing units behind the walls, which makes archer spam less viable, or even better, forces you to have melee units to draw fire on them. There are still a few units with limited to no use, like axeman, horseman and footknight (the alternatives are just better), but the game is already in a very good spot. Content wise, campaign is story rich, however the cutscenes could use a button to skip to next animation. I also hope we get some extended research, more naval team, etc. I know devs won't do it, but I will ask once again for multiplayer :)

I want to lead this by saying I SUCK at RTS games, partially because I am often a lazy gamer. To me, they've always felt like trying to cook dinner while cleaning house and helping someone with homework at the same time while the pets are knocking things off tables. As you may imagine, this game has been kicking my ass. Now, I'm going to recommend it anyway. Why? Because this is one of the very few RTS games that makes me WANT to try harder and get better at working in four places at once. The economy is the right level of complex, the buff buildings make a massive difference without being obnoxious to place, the fortifications are impactful and straightforward, the units on both sides have good variety, and the combat feels fantastic to control and observe. There are obvious and apt comparisons to They Are Billions, but there are some major differences that need to be addressed. Most resource deposits eventually run out, population and food are consumed instead of being static "capacity" numbers, the scale of the map and your economy is much larger, and, most importantly to me, the game is actually balanced around losing units and buildings on a regular basis. A group of spearmen will handily hold a breach in the walls, often trading one of their lives for 30 or so rebels or just body blocking while the remaining archers continue shooting. Units are generally cheap and quick to train while still being much stronger than the horde units you'll be facing. I still die much earlier than I should, but I can at least see the solutions to apply next time. Thankfully, it's not just "click more, faster" like too many RTS games feel. One day, I'll survive the hulk wave without being crippled.

Right now, no. The balancing is way off on missions. On level 3 the difficult ramps up insanely. As a new player, unfamiliar with the game, it was too much frustration to continue. The first level buildings are upgraded, two new resources are used, a whole host of new buildings come into play and your hit by a constant stream of enemies while trying build up to face the larger waves. Plus, in the forum a similar observation is raised and a dev leaves perhaps one of the most asinine remarks I've seen from a developer (to paraphrase) "I completed the level on the hardest level and beat it first time". Well woopie-di-do and lardy dar for you, bucko. A player takes the time to make a valid observation, expressing how there may be a hurdle to new players, and the dev blows them off with that BS attitude. Not everyone is in an indoctrinated acolyte of the Cult of Difficult and maybe, just maybe, the dev could take their observation and consider it as free product feedback rather than launch a "git gud" barrage. I like the game, genuinely has funny cut scenes, cute functional graphics, and a solid RTS, but it definitely needs better balancing on levels so far, and the devs attitude stinks if that was their response. I hope that was a one off.

Ever play Starcraft 2 Terran campaign? Remember the mission where you are in the middle of the map, and there are infected terran and zerg in all 360 directions, and the goal is to wipe out all enemies surrounding you? (attack during the night) Well this game is basically that SC2 mission/They Are Billions with it's own unique combat system and econ etc. if you enjoyed that mission, this game is that mission x10. Devs have an enjoyable British cheeky sense of humor. Solid seemingly balanced game after 6h. Just gimme Starcraft 3 dammit.

I can't recommend this. It is micromanaging in the worst possible ways. You manually shut the gates, otherwise enemy troops just walk right in, but if you shut the gate, then resource gathering outside the walls. I don't know why I can't build a farm, It let's me place it, then disappears, so I am always struggling to get my village fed. I get that the waves come, those are fine, but after clearing the map of enemy peasants, why do random one person attacker show up in the middle of the village? The mini map shows the location of the attack, but it disappears and then you have to wait for the game to announce it again. I don't want to have to hunt for literally 1 enemy that is running loose in the middle of my village. I bought this early access and had a lot more hope for it, but it is more of a chore than an enjoyable experience.

I do not enjoy this game at all... I struggle alot with the overview of the resources / management of vilagers. I have builders, but where are they? Has my fishery run out of fish? Apperantly so! What dictates how many workers I get each day? I can't get a grip of how the food demand/production equation works. There is a stats panel but I dont find any meaningful info there. Summary is that I feel like I have no idea what happens with the macro in this game. In AoE2 I have alot going on but I still know whats going on with my resources all the time. Maybe it's a combination of the visual style of the game and the hud that confuses me? It's very frustrating. The tutorial was imo way to short and did not explain enough of the systems. And it's way to rushy for me. The day timer is too short and the constant guessing where the enemy will come from is annoing. The micro becomes very cumbersome just opening gates, closing gates, putting archers in towers, taking them down from towers and send them to another tower. Oh and the cutscenes between missions. It's nice that there is some semblance of a story. But dang, they are slow and uneventful to watch. Just found myself skipping all of them. They need to be sped up 10x

Been waiting to get this game until the 1.0 release but I'm not sure it is ready.Granted I have not made it too far into the game yet and and enjoying the base building/exploration parts of the game. My issues lie exclusively with the combat/npc pathfinding so far as I am already having issues with their pathfinding causing them to get stuck and not be functionally useless until I can unstick them or destroy what they are stuck on. Controlling the combat troops isn't what I would want either as there doesn't seem to be any kind select all and the ability to create seperate groups was ignored in the tutorial. When commanding troops they can sometimes just choose not to move or if you select an enemy who dies they will stand there as if a whole group isn't behind them. I am optimistic about the game as the basis is enjoyable and most of my gripes are probably easily patchable but I was waiting for the 1.0 release specifically to avoid things like this, but I will probably give it more time soon and update if my opinion changes. Update:I've played a bit more now and the issues above all still feel prevalent, I also have becoming irritated with the cutscenes which seem to assume the average player has the reading speed of a decomposing corpse and love extremely long gaps between everything, which ruins what would otherwise be decently amusing scenes. I'm probably gonna keep coming back to it as it gives me nostalgia about halo wars as a kid and their is a good game underneath these issues, but I still can't really recommend it to others YET (I'm choosing to be optimistic despite the games industry regularly proving that to be a dumb choice)

Seems fun so far, but: - Painfully slow cutscenes that you either have to skip and miss the story, or watch for minutes on end. There needs to be a skip-to-next-sentence function when you click the mouse or push enter or spacebar. - Resources aren't well explained - do berry bushes regrow? Do trees regrow or is wood a finite resource? What does a builder's house do? I can already build. How many resources does each picker house bring in per day? Why aren't my buildings being built - I have enough workers and resources, don't I? - Autorepair should repair walls that were destroyed. - Pushing escape to cancel an action keeps kicking me out to the main menu. - The balance is really bad - six easy enemy waves countered with hand of god laser beam spells. Then a final wave from all directions with catapults and trolls that none of your units can counter, and no spells left. Why are there even spells in a stronghold game - it makes all the defence building pointless when one click destroys their entire wave.

If you like what you see in the video and screenshots you can buy with confidence. There are some factors which may give some people pause for thought where others will be pleased to see. Among these are:- 1. Maps are proceduraly generated - Although you'll start a map in the same location with the same rules the map will be different every time. This can cause a map to be easy on one play through and then mind meltingley hard on the next. 2. Not always clear how hard a map is going to be - Although there's 1 or 2 maps which are almost always an easy start, it's not immediately clear what you're walking into. This, however, may be down to me being a little dumb/menu blind. 3. The horde is real! You're not going to be going up against the massive numbers and diverse enemies you're seeing right away. This game is hard (at least for me) and it took lots of failed attempts before I got to a point where I was defending against these huge armies with a well appointed base.

I don't take the time to review many games. But this here is hands down one of my favorite RTS games period. My top 5 favorite RTS/ Strategy games or series I can say. Would be Stronghold series, Age of mythology/ empires, Starcraft, Black and White 1 & 2, then now Diplomacy is not an option. This game reminds me of a new Stronghold game. It has some neat QOL features and mechanics. It is a full blown nostalgic trip and an addiction. I can't get enough of this game right now. Plus the procedural generation is a smart and great replay value. It helps with new tactics or strategies. It changes where resources or enemies may be. It changes the way you think in playstyle. I could say so much more. But it's still early access. So I want to leave room for more. When full release comes. I love the magic system and how upgrades work. I can't stop thinking about it. Even as I'm writing this at work. I just want to play Diplomacy. If you like Stronghold or RTS games. This game is 1000% recommended. I actually plan on picking there other game up too. This company deserves to have high praise. Great game here and one of the best times I've had, since playing Stronghold. I think this and the new Age of Mythology Remake will be getting lots of hours in the coming years. Absolutely a phenomenal time to be had and many hours lost. You just want to keep playing one more game.

8/4/24: I really want to like this game, but the combat mechanics and size of enemy waves is just plain ridiculous (normal difficulty). My troops have to be ordered to fight constantly, or they'll stand around and let themselves and the town be destroyed (often times, I order them to attack and they either ignore my order, or they'll fight the single troop I've clicked on and then ignore the 25 others that are actively burning down the town 15 feet in front of them. Enemy wave size is completely unbalanced, currently. The final wave of the first campaign mission, I had 75-100 enemies attacking my town... I was still trying to develop the town and grow my defenses, I find myself never having time to adequately prepare for the next wave. And not in a good way. Also development of this game seems to be extremelyyyy slow.

I find "Diplomacy is Not an Option" absolutely incredible ! The mechanics are both deep and accessible, providing a real challenge with a selectable difficulty range . I want to build an empire, but talk to the neighbors ? No thanks, I’ve got catapults for that ! The villagers complain, enemies swarm by the hundreds, but me ? I handle it all with an army of not-so-motivated peasants and a wall that’s barely standing . Honestly, diplomacy is overrated when you can just fling catapult shots !

**Review updated** Buy this game. It scratches a deep itch for gamers. Even the enjoyment I got out of the first 2 hours is worth the asking price. This is pretty clearly inspired by Stronghold, the incredible RTS castle builder from 2001. That's not usually a good thing; Stronghold still runs well, plays well, and looks gorgeous, 23 years later. Few good competitors have come around because of just how incredible Stronghold actually is. Diplomacy is Not an Option takes that as a compliment. It is on par with Stronghold. It is enjoyable through and through, offering a good challenge and progression tree. What really amazes me is how the game focuses on the parts we care about. The layout of defenses is what matters most; resource management tends to be pretty easy. Even if you only play for two hours, buy this game.

This is one of those games where I desperately wish for a mixed review because I'm aware my experience is pretty subjective. This game is WONDERFULLY fun, its a great RTS with some fun features that make it stick out from others of its ilk, but as somone who tends to turtle in RTSes the difficulty ramps up way too fast in my opinion. It has good economy difficulty ramp, but with the limitations of citizens movement its hard to scale that hill at a pace to match the speed of the incoming waves difficulty, so I usually end up getting wiped by the fifth of sixth waves. What makes it so difficult is that the gameplay is SO MUCH fun. This might just be a skill issue so, if you enjoy difficult RTSes GO for it, you'll have a blast

Good casual RTS game that love defence! From a veteran of RTS game, the game has pause/play/speed-up game speed elements that allow players to catch up on their economy and base building delegations. It's centered around base defence PVE style where you defeat waves of a few factioned hordes. Microing units isn't as focused as much compared to base placements and planning your progression towards higher tiers of the game. The unit AI is simple and the command menu can change attack priorities which gives the option to the player in how they want to eliminate opposing units. There are different game modes that tweak the goals and objectives of the game which is really good for players who want to experience the game with altered starting/ending resources and objectives. For casual players who have no prior experience to how RTS games should be played, the game can improve on the tutorials because, in the normal and campaign mode settings, players might not be able to unlock further tiers of technology or even survive long enough in the game, if those new players don't know what to prioritize in the game. Aside from what was mentioned, overall solid defence RTS game. It'll definitely deliver on the defensive tactic many commanding officers are looking for. ^^

Game is not balanced. Not worth buying.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone who is interested in tower defense games and city builders - if you always wanted your city builder to have some pressure or military side to it, this is for you. It's very charming and a fun short session style builder (with speed up mechanics). If you've never tried a game like this, I recommend it. It is a straightforward game that can be easy but has a high skill ceiling. It has a sandbox mode and will have a campaign. If you are a new player to the genre, you can stop reading here. For genre veterans; If you came here from They Are Billions or any similar city builder/tower defender looking for more, I am sad to inform you it doesn't do what TAB does better in any way. Again, I only brushed the surface, but the combat doesn't work as well, the maps aren't as large, and the concept isn't as interesting. The tech tree is very straight forward, there are limited enemy types, and even the method of expansion on the map is less interesting. There's less to do overall in almost every category. If you are looking for more They Are Billions, your wait must continue - because this game adds nothing.

I love this game. First off, I enjoyed it for at least 35 hours (some levels can be pretty long but you can easily come back to them later). This satisfies the minimum $1-1 hour ratio, and I haven't even 100% completed all of the challenges. Second, it is essentially a series of sandbox and endless maps (for now), but I am looking forward to the potential of this game. I had 100% completed TAB (They are Billions, a hardcore RTS game), and both games have the same general concept (with random map & enemy horde generation, waves, city-building, etc.). Moreover, I think the medieval route with magic (which definitely should be expanded, with magic units perhaps) and the infection mechanics are great. Third, the point of this game is a challenge yourself by building vast armies and/or defenses to combat massive waves of enemies (do not underestimate your enemies!), so it is more of a fast-paced massive RTS (with a pause button and save mechanics, of course). There is already plenty to do, and the devs are pretty clear and transparent in their updates (which is a great sign). Overall, the game will be pretty enjoyable (and challenging if you like playing Ultra-Hardcore), and I think there is a lot of future potential with the stable base content.

Brilliant little addition to the RTS genre, with a lot more meat to it than the cute graphics would suggest. It feels like a spiritual successor to the Stronghold series, as you work to build walls, traps, and a variety of tiny little warriors to defend your ever-expanding economy. Having to feed your troops as well as your citizens makes economic management a careful balancing act, as building too big of an army will create a deadly famine, while focusing too much of your economy will place it in danger of the ever-expanding waves of attackers. The real strength of the game, though, is the graphics. I've seen plenty of games attempt a low-poly style and end up feeling soulless and generic. This one does the opposite - it oozes character and charm. The characters, buildings, and warriors all have beautifully detailed animations, and you can happily spend a good while watching your little smiths tinker away in their forges, your lumberjacks haul logs back from the forest, or a squad of spearmen face off against a horde of peasants. The choice of enemies is similarly delightful. Huge, teeming waves of low-HP attackers make for delightfully satisfying fights, made even better by the physics-enabled impacts that throw them into the air. Even losing the game becomes a visually satisfying experience, as you watch the enemy pour into your base. And somehow, it still runs as smooth as butter - I didn't get any FPS drop even when the waves became colossal. Highly recommend.

Kind of a mix between Age of Empires and They Are Billions, but better than both. Its still pretty early on in the early access so there isn't very much story content, however the challenge mode has kept me occupied for hours and is enjoyable if you like the gameplay loop of the newer tower defense/RTS genre that's become popular lately.

Ever enjoyed turtling up in age of empires or command and conquer, and watch coldly from your throne in cathartic megalomania as endless legions of the pathetic vermin that once dared oppose you now crashes in impotent violence against the cold, merciless might of your carefully crafted dominions, protected by the most talented artisans in the art of bloodshed and slaughter? No? just me?..... Aaaaanyway, it seems to me that the devs are going for something like that, and did pretty good at it too, so far. It's quite similar to the games i mentioned earlier but without the clutter and micromanaging of having to balance several diferent factions, tech trees and the like. There's still some of that, enought to make a difference but not that time consuming or annoying. There's also several attacking factions with different aspects to them to keep in mind when defending, etc. All in all, an excellent primary gamplay loop with a lot of versatility but without much depth, and cathartic action that even at its most complacent moments manages to keep you engaged and on your toes. The only real con is that there's not that much variety in general and a few qualities of life improvement can be seen missing here and there, but hey, that's what early access is for. Bottom line: having a lot of fun with it and looking foward to see what the devs cook up for the next update. Also, it's ok if it isn't for you.

A small, but great RTS/city building game. You start as a small castle with a meager amount of resources, soldiers, and residents; and you must expand your territory through scouting, city-building, resource acquisition/management, technological development, and military might. You must defend your kingdom from hordes that come every few days, and expand into a hostile territory whose occupants only grow in strength the further you venture from your castle. Due to the nature of hordes growing in strength as time goes on, you must research better tech and increase the proficiency/size of your army with every passing day. You must wall off your entire kingdom so hordes can't just waltz on through. Every mode ranges in difficulty, from easy to practically impossible. Once you get used to the game's mechanics, you can play this while listening to music/videos. I highly recommend this game to those who enjoy city building/horde defense games.

Overall this is a great game - mixes elements of Stronghold and They Are Billions games. If you like either or both of those, you'll probably like this one. PROS: 1) Zoom in and out levels are great - high overview and then detail up close is pretty nice. I don't feel restricted in the camera zoom or rotation. 2) Troop formation control is good - simple and intuitive: Mouse drag to set direction while simultaneously using keyboard to select arrangement of your formation, which is basically various sizes of line, block and column. Select guard mode so that your swordsmen stay disciplined in the line to guard your archers. Swordsmen will do their job when enemies get close enough. Developers might want to consider tactical pre-sets for formations too, like hollow square and wedge formations for example. 3) Economy buildings are diverse and interesting, keeping the interplay of resources an important aspect of the game. 4) Tech tree is nice - graphic style is creative. Military units, medical, worker speed, trade, etc. are upgrade choices that you make. 5) Obelisk powers add a nice fantasy aspect to the game - nothing like hitting that mob of ghouls with a meteor! 6) You can have a lot of units and enemies on the battlefield at once. 7) You can choose to build your town and castle walls the way you want. CONS - as of the current Beta version: 1) Attacks come on a timer, and the problem is that sometimes it takes quite awhile to defeat the current wave of attackers. Meanwhile the clock is still ticking and the next wave is on top of you before you have time to repair, rebuild and create more troops. This is frustrating especially if you have just finished an epic defense of your town. The amount of time invested in building up vs. the speedy overwhelming defeat seems unbalanced and not as much fun as if you could eke out the survival of your town and live to fight another day. A simple fix would be to have the timer start after the current battle is over. Or perhaps another possible fix would be to award gems for an epic defense, to use the obelisk powers to defend against the next wave, while you rebuild - so still keeping it challenging, but possible to pull out a win from that next immediate wave.

Ah, this game scratches a particularly good itch for me. Tower defence, city builder with huge waves of enemies. Build your medieval city from the ground up and raise an army. Set up a strike force of horsemen and ambush those pesky enemy catapults assaulting your walls. Make ripples in the sea of enemies with your trebuchet that can throw its 90 kg stone projectiles over 300 meters and splash into the dense mass of humans that oppose your reign. Anyway: +cool low poly art style +loving the unit sounds +cool mechanic with having to handle the bodies from battlefields or sickness +several different game modes +/-the humor is sometimes a bit hit or miss for me -projectile units are retarded as all hell and will fire into walls if you don't babysit them -wish there was an easier way to manage unit special skills What I hope to see in the future: Paved roads Seasons Water management A town bell to make all the workers get inside the town before I close all the gates Gallows to hang traitors from

Highly recommend for anybody interested in games like banished and similar. Personal feedback: One thing I think could be very helpful is a tech queue and maybe have the tech button flash when you finish research, I also think maybe having troops level up could be a cool idea but I think that would be better left to a mod if this game ever gets workshop support. I also think having walkways would be nice, as normally in these games they allow people to walk faster along them, and it would also help greatly in visualizing where you might want buildings in the future. In the same vein maybe having a sticker feature like in Civilization 6 so you can give the map a once over and decide what things you want where, place all the markers for things on the ground, and go back to it later once you can actually build it, would be pretty cool.

- Trebucheds and archers are very useless to shoot behind walls, they usually shoot at the walls. - Mounted units have almost no function. - When the trebuched hits the units near the wall, the men glitches and goes inside. - The research chart offers very little content. - Builders should be able to automatically build demolished buildings. In the late game, rebuilding the walls with each attack is like torture! - It gives a warning when a troop is stuck between buildings, but does not show where the trapped person is stuck. It's not much fun looking for him for two hours. - In the late game, you usually only spam and slaughter troops, not much content, new soldiers and structures are absolutely necessary. - We need new spells too... - There should be an option to order the trebucheds to shoot where the most troops are ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ - Mounted units would be very useful if they were given an option to rush into enemies and come back. - Trebuches should be made higher angle and slower but able to shoot behind walls. (Same for archers and other units.)

Its definitely a fun game very much a tower defense city management feel. the only thing i dont like is the lack of proactive/offensive options. that being said, its tower defense so ur not supposed to be able to curtail the offensive...but imho this game feels like it should have it. or at least offer a game mode with such. would really like to be able to take the fight to my opponent instead of holding out as long as possible. regardless this game is fun, the UI is good and the gfx are legit. something very rewarding about lazing a horde just as they are about to overwhelm ur troops/walls. devs if ur reading this id love to see a game mode where the assaults dont start until u "clear" the map of the local hostiles. would be cool to be able to build up first before the wave assaults begin. i know theres modes where the assaults are slower/take more days to initiate, but as a noob (and a perfectionist) its still too fast for my taste. coupling that with the need to expand as u progress makes it hard to lay out effective walls beforehand. just my 2 cents. OH! an alternate method for earning crystals (or whatever the unit is that allows the godlike abilities) would be very welcome. i appreciate the challenge of the limited amount, but would be cool to not contend with that too. maybe require worship or something time based which requires workers but is otherwise renewable/sustainable. anyway, this is a fun tower defense city manager RTS. i give it a good ol recommend, i can see this being a main-stay for me, especially if the devs keep adding to it.

So... Given that I have played this game for >800 hours to date (omg, how do I do facepalm emoji?), my review will hopefully be of some use to someone! Firstly, I love this game! The design, the humour, game play, most aspects in fact make this one of the most fun RTS I have possibly ever played...it's brilliant.. BUT... The one (and I truly think this is the only one) FATAL downfall that drives me insane about this game is the difficulty system.. It seems to me (a casual gamer of limited talent I am sure), that the easy mode is just too easy, but anything beyond that is just too difficult, and then the challenging modes are utterly pointless/total waste of time. It is immeasurably frustrating to constantly lose at the same time within every game regardless of the strategy you try to employ, the resources & time available to recoup from successive waves of attack are diminished so much that it is impossible to succeed beyond a set time frame, it is a zero sum situation that leaves you utterly downtrodden. I don't need a game to give me impossible odds, that is what life is for! I want something that gives me a consistent fighting chance so I can escape into an entertaining world where I get to overcome the odds! Isn't that why we have entertainment? Please fix the difficulty system, or provide options to adjust the odds, and this is an absolute gem for the ages...right now it has become utterly disheartening... UPDATE: Difficulty system is still a joke.... :(

I like these games-Age of Darkness/TABs. Usually i like the realistic gritty ones. But I really like the brighter graphics on this one. I also think the game play is better, with more varied/fun units. But here is what i REALLY like about this one over those: In those games, it's really hard to expand, and space itself is a valuable resource. It's a good mechanic, really. But it means you essentially have to just blob down structures and cannot build fortifications in a magnificent fashion. Not so here. Here, you can build a huge, open fantastic fortification-or system of fortifications. You still better be careful expanding. And maybe some won't like that you don't have the added challenge of tight quarters. But I really like it. Anyway, this is just a fun, easy to get into RTS/defender with fun graphics, reasonable system requirements(now) and a lot of freedom. In short, it's a good game.

This feels like a game I might love one day. Good base game for sure. The "demo?" campaign is a short two missions you can knockout in a couple hours. Endless mode is quite fun initially but after a couples plays it gets boring with the current units, buildings, and tech trees (imo). I imagine a lot more is coming and that should make it repeatable and introduce different strategies. Overall, cool. I guess I thought it would be further along after a year+ in early access. Recommended on sale if you like the genre- just know you are not getting a lot at this point.

Got more than I expected with this game. I was thinking it was going to be a base building/tower defense game, but was really overwhelmed by how much there was to do and control. Trying to keep an eye on food and resources and enemies and dispose of dead bodies and try to fight/defend yourself from hordes, a little much for me. Definitely not something I would recommend if you enjoy being able to hop on for a few minutes and then hop off, this one takes time and attention to detail. So for me, the game is a little daunting and I keep starting it up, and then uninstalling it because I get overwhelmed. The game is great looking and seems fun, but do not mistake it for something easy like I did.

Diplomacy is Not an Option provides a solid gaming experience, where the bright green grass not only adds a pop of color but also ensures excellent visibility of your relentless enemies. Their brutal attempts at diplomacy sadly fall short, much to their demise. In this unforgiving world, there are no negotiations with the leader of the attackers, no prisoners taken, and no mercy shown. And why is that, you might ask? It all started when they hurt my dog at the beginning of the game, awakening a ruthless avenger within me (not unlike the infamous John Wick). As you embark on your vengeance-fueled journey, you'll find yourself embracing the same unwavering determination and lack of compassion that John Wick is known for. After all, when diplomacy fails, there's only one thing left to do – show them why it's not an option. In conclusion, Diplomacy is Not an Option offers a thrilling adventure where mercy and negotiations have no place. With its eye-catching scenery and a storyline that sparks a fire within, you'll quickly discover that in this world, it's either fight or be defeated.

Overall, the game is pretty enjoyable. I didn't encounter any bugs or issues that impacted my playtime (roughly 15 hours), and everything seemed to work as intended. So why do I not recommend the game? This game has been in early access for over a year at this point and there have been basically ZERO updates. No new content, no balancing tweaks, no additional campaign missions or map changes for endless mode. As it stands now, I pushed it a bit longer than I normally would for the amount of content that is in the game by getting my 15 hours. It just doesn't have enough going for it to justify the price tag, and without seeing regular (or ANY) updates, I just don't have faith at this point that the game will continue growing. Hope they prove me wrong.

Diplo has a full 3D camera that can view the game from any angle you please. Came back to this game after giving it a break, tried all day to give it an honest go and the program crashed 3 times today, and lags so freaking badly during game play. I really hope they fix the issues with this game as it has so much potential to be so fun but not in it's current form.

I recently played "Diplomacy is Not an Option" and I was thoroughly impressed by this real-time strategy game. The graphics are top-notch, with detailed units and environments that truly bring the world to life. The game mechanics are solid, with intuitive controls and a deep tech tree that provides a sense of progression and keeps things interesting. The single-player campaign is well-designed, providing a challenging and rewarding experience. The multiplayer mode is also a great addition, allowing players to test their skills against others online. The battles are intense and fast-paced, requiring quick thinking and strategic planning. One of the things I appreciate about this game is the attention to detail. The developers have clearly put a lot of thought into the game, from the different unit types and abilities to the resource management and base-building elements. All of these elements work together seamlessly to create a truly enjoyable experience. In conclusion, "Diplomacy is Not an Option" is a fantastic real-time strategy game that I would highly recommend to fans of the genre. It's well-crafted, challenging, and enjoyable, providing hours of entertainment. If you're looking for a solid RTS game, look no further than "Diplomacy is Not an Option".

Really FUN RTS game, a MUST BUY!! Note: Only two maps available in current BETA, but it is well worth it to play! The game is similar in some ways to TAB (They Are Billions), but with various differences both aesthetically and functionally. I like that you can traverse through the trees with a minor movement debuff, I've always hated RTS games that present trees as walls. I like that all resources in the game (trees, fish, ore) have a limit to their availability, making them finite. Challenging modes are definitely challenging! Balancing growth (upgrades, military units, research), with expansion, and the development of defensive structures in appropriate areas is critical to success. Quickly identifying small gaps between cliffs where you can build short and sustainable walls helps! Can't wait to play more levels!

This game reminds me of STRONGHOLD... and older game that had better graphics. This is a simplified version of the medieval warfare game of castles and catapults. I like this one because of the "chill" factor. The designers didn't take themselves too seriously. They made a game where you could get a basic economy and have basic troops with some degree of difference in performance. By taking the path of least resistance, they gave us a game that has fun and strategy but goes easy on the learning curve and brain burn. There may still be bits of that if you ramp up the level of difficulty but it is entirely possible to learn the game quickly and have fun at the lesser levels. Graphics are not a strong point but they aren't poor either. You can clearly make out the buildings as well as the flora and fauna. It does not strive for strict realism but there are doses of that. Dead bodies left littering your home area cause people to get unhappy and even ill. Economics rears its ugly head to bring life in the game closer to reality but once you learn what to build and when, the game can be forgiving of little mistakes. Politics are ignored and I for one am pleased they are. Health issues are left at a basic level but not too basic. You must consider you populace while you are waging war. This can be a fun "tower defense" game or ramped up to be a serfdom mini-simulator. Some thought and good choices were put into the design which made it easier to enjoy this game. If you are looking for an uber-serious simulation, keep on moving. If you are looking for an inexpensive game that will make you think a bit about strategy while eating away time without too much stress? This is well worth you time and effort.

This is surprisingly well-polished indie survival RTS that is great fun! As of this writing (12/26/2022) you get the following: - 3 difficulty levels - 2 campaign levels, one of which gives you a choice of which enemies to fight - 5 or 6 challenge levels, each with 3-4 changes on the challenge The gameplay is a great little RTS that has your fairly durable forces fighting against literally tens of thousands of enemies on some of the longer maps; however, those durable forces can easily be overwhelmed by the hordes that come at you. Tier for tier, unit for unit, you have a more powerful army, but you'll need it to compensate for their numbers. My only complaint so far is that it's not out yet! You will probably like this if you: - Like playing RTS games - Like playing defense against hordes of enemies - Enjoy games like They are Billions or playing custom games in Age of Empires, Starcraft, or Supreme Commander where you're holding out against an overwhelming force Highly recommend, even more highly when it's on sale. I look forward to this game becoming version 1.0!

Ever wanted a cool tower defense game but takes 0 actual skill and setup and you have to use guides and know your "build order" just to survive the "medium" difficulty? Ever wanted RNG in your game to make sure you have to constantly reroll maps just to have a single hope of survival? Yeah, that's this game in a nutshell. The balancing for endless more is completely off, going from the easiest mode you can take a nap and still survive, while the medium difficulty makes sure to end your entire career because you got a garbage map set up that keeps you below the difficulty curve. The difficulty scaling of waves needs to be completely overhauled as you don't even get a chance by the 4 wave. Resources a joke, everything requires wood, yet wood cannot be replanted, leading to you being forced to expand to keep up with demand, which then leads to more food demand, which leads to more food sources, which leads to more wood. In order to keep up with his crazy cycle of wood demand you have to expand and make you base bigger, but as you make it bigger you need to make more and more walls just to secure weakness, yet there are hardly any choke points in a tower defense game, so expect to expand in a 360 map just to get stone, iron, and wood which are FINITE early game. Honestly the worst economic tower defense game I've played which punishes you for expanding, yet you NEED to if you get bad mountains, stone, or metal. This game forces perfection on any difficulty just to keep pace with the waves of enemies. By far it is the least relaxing tower defense game on the market, go play any other, at least you'll enjoy your time instead of hitting the reset button after an hour of failure again and again. Edit 8/13/24: Played the game again after years. I don't think a single thing has changed. Trash difficulty curve, RNG, limited resources, literally nothing has changed. I don't even see new units, maps, or anything except the sandbox mode. The sandbox mode kind of sucks to, making your options so limited. I'd like to actually see the devs play their own game without cheating in crap or you know, surviving past wave 4.

Love this game, but it needs to be balanced out!!! If they can tweak it to help balance it, it would be even better! It is really hard/possible to recover after a massive first wave in just 4 days, and then the second massive wave comes and you completely get wiped out! I barely have any time to build up an army let alone build up resources and buildings. On top of that there are also massive hordes of enemies way more powerful then you all over the map, blocking you from getting the resources you need to grow! So while your building your army up for an attack you also have to use that small army to attack enemies in your way further weakening yourself so you can get crushed by the next wave!!!! I like playing it but so far it feels massively unbalanced against you and I wish I could get to a lvl 3 town hall lol. So far I have not made it. I understand it shouldn't be super easy but right now it feels impossible to win on some missions. If there was a way to get resources faster or get your population to grow almost instantly when you build more buildings, rather then waiting days for results? Or lowering the amount of enemies around on the maps so your units don't get so destroyed? Or after you defeat a wave of enemies you get a bonus amount of resources after to help you recover slightly? I don't know, I think they have a great game and its a lot of fun to play, I am just feeling like I am missing something in order for me to experience more of the features the game has to offer. I have barely been able to make it to Town Hall II and have spent all my resources doing so. It doesn't even seem like there are enough resources on the map to get you past Town Hall II some times. I hope this gets seen and can be further balanced and or tweaked. They look like they spent a lot of time on the buildings, units, terrain, building materials, and enemy units! Really like this game and think it can go even further where the player isn't so beet up from having to multitask so much they miss out on things and can make it to the final wave more prepared. That or maybe its just me, and I am missing something, and I need to work on understanding the game more?

Diplomacy is Not an Option plays out like a pretty conventional RTS. You gather resources, kick start your production, and hire builders and soldiers to do gruntwork. The gimmick is that your enemy doesn’t have a base of operation. Instead, they attack you in waves from outside the map boundaries, at set intervals. Sort of like in a tower defense game. You know where they come from too, giving you some space to focus your defenses. And as a last push in their final attack, they also gather up stray units from encampments around the map -- giving you some mitigating busywork to do between the earlier waves. It’s fine. But I think I might have raised my hopes up a little too high. The marketing material makes it seem like this epic tower defense game, where you defend your bastion from closing armies. A real focus on scale and excess. Huge crescendos. Massive armies. Yet, the game starts out with such humble beginnings. Small armies defending tiny castles, with barely enough resources and units to go around. It’s both slow and punishing, never really reaching those epic proportions. It sort of just fizzles, somewhat unceremoniously. I’m sure it will reach those heights eventually. I’m just not interested in playing for tens of hours just to [i]eventually[/i] reach that point, when it feels like it should have been the core experience from the get-go. It’s a matter of expectations I guess. But it’s a pass for me either way. I feel like I’ve played Diplomacy is Not an Option a million times before.

**UPDATE** WOW! These devs know how to make a game great. Nearly everything I posted below has been fixed, added, and improved upon. Great job! ~~~~~~~~~ The Good: --Fun and challenging gameplay. Units are varied and fun to use. Spells are a blast to use. Decent amount of varied and fun scenarios to play in Endless and Challenge modes. The Bad: --Campaign isn't finished with only 3 levels available. No editor for scenarios, endless modes, etc. Thu Ugly: --Crashes at least 1-3 times a play session (2-3 hrs) if not more Needs: --Map editor and scenario creator --A way to queue up research if materials are available --Better route AI for workers or allow them to go through walls --A way to see the crystals and carts within the trees better would be good or just auto-pickup if relatively close. --Queuing up multiple different trades in the market instead of only one

The base game is fun, but the current design feels scummy. The available campaign content seems designed to ensure that people get through the refund window before realizing that the campaign only includes two missions. Be up front about it; this is an early access game. The starting continent has map locations and flags as if it will allow progression, and the eastern continent is shaded out to suggest coming content. The problem is that you literally unlock two map points on the starting continent and hit the end of the available missions. This will likely be a fun game, and I think it was worth the money for me, but wait on it until things are communicated clearly and the price makes sense for the available content.

Pros: +Humorous campaign cut scenes +Diverse enemy types +Content that has been released is highly polished +Significant depth in city and defense planning +High Quality voice acting +Multiple game modes to keep you engaged Cons: -Game is not finished yet -Not a significant need to use melee troops when towers and archers are easier to keep alive -Updates come out slowly -Only 2 playable missions in campaign -Lack of variety to units in each enemy type -No research queue Personal Opinion: Diplomacy is Not an Option (DNO) offers thrilling real time strategy that also happens to be a tower defense and city management game. The more I learn about the game the more I want to play. It can be easy to overlook the complexity and depth of city and defense layout, but it all starts by realizing how building storage next to production increases the rate of materials harvested, and how water fountains increase the population of nearby houses, or how builder houses need to be dispersed throughout the city in order to reduce the time it takes a builder to get to a construction site, and so on. There are quite a few different enemy types like undead, peasants, royal army, but there are not a large variety of units in each type, hopefully more will be added in the future. Campaign cut scenes are very amusing and I found myself looking forward to each one, which made learning the campaign isn't complete all that much more disappointing. As it currently is DNO is a great little game, and with more features to be added it should be worth looking forward to what comes next!

The game presents this as a meaningful option but its actually a funny little thing they're doing where they're tricking you with the option that you might be able to meaningfully interact with that half of the game, than slamming your knuckles but making literally every unit on that side a piece of shit and every mission unwinnably hard, thus demonstrating that haha, if you were the other guy you'd stay winning, but you defected and are thus: fucked out've luck. Also we've locked the option to go back... enjoy this extended jokey joke we're doing where we're mangling our own mechanics in a sort've parody of ourselves in order to demonstrate that the idea you might wanna I dunno, play as a different faction, is laughably silly! Those guys are stink idiots and you wanna be one?? Haha! I'm just saying devs, the only person who looks like a fucking moron in this honking farce isn't the player who clicked the button, but its you shitting your own jester costume on stage trying to make this tortured point in front of my unamused face. Either have two factions or don't. Including it as a sort've trap option joke that can fuck you SO early just makes you look like you don't know how to balance your own goddamn game.

Actually a cool game, reminds a bit of the old Stronghold feeling. Unfortunately, the difficulty level fluctuates a lot and is not very well balanced - especially in Endless Mode. So it happens that on the easiest difficulty level you bounce off the waves very quickly, while on medium it is partly - for me - unmanageable. In addition, the time between the waves is very long on easy and very short on medium. The unit types are crazy - only hulk and several siege units at Day 23 on Medium. The random aspect - from where and how many waves - does the rest. If the developers still work on this, I'll give it a recommendation.

I am a big fan of RTS games such as Age of mythology, Age of empires, Rise of nations, they are billions and Battle for middle earth. One of the things I did find a little lacking was in half of these games listed above was the lack of massive Waves of enemies to fend off or massive armies battling it out which I feel like after an hour of game play this game delivers very well on. This feels like a Lord of the rings type of RTS with the peasants looking like orcs/ Uruk-Hai and massive castle battles like in lord of the rings. This game is a rather easy game to micro manage resources and population with little to no repercussions compared to They are billions. I can see this game being quite repetitive in terms of game play as you are playing the same tech tree over. would be cool to see in future being able to play different races with different troops and playing styles such as vikings having strong axe men and better wood gain or the British having better archery and better towers. overall good game concept. not bad for early access. Graphics quality: 5/10 Micro managing difficulty: 4/10 Game play: 6/10 Tech Tree: 6/10 Base building: 7/10 Battle size: 9/10 repetitiveness: 6/10 overall 6.5/10

What is surprising, is the depth of this game which at first looks a casual and easy going filler for your time. Its actually like the "They Are Billions" game but with a dose of dark humor and catooney graphics which makes the fun even better. The game still can be hardcore if you raise the difficulty. This game is like a mix of city building, RTS, and tower defense games, and the exciting part is that you don’t have to like all of them to enjoy the game. For example, if you only want to build your dream city in peace, you can turn off the enemy altogether. However this game is very much a work in progress, it needs more content on all three aspects of the game. The city building part is especially lacking in depth: there needs to be more building types and complex mechanics for it to be interesting. As of right now, RTS and tower defense seem to be their main focus, city building feels more like a supplement to them. I enjoyed taking a small army to explore the surroundings and uncover the fog of war, and occasionally using my cavalry to crush the enemies, but there isn’t much else you can do with your units. Things like different formations, active skills, and flanking bonus from the Total War series will be good additions to the game. I also would like to see more defense towers added to the game. Currently, you just put your archers and siege weapons on the wall and that’s it. On a side note, this game desperately needs more Steam Cloud storage space. 100MB is simply not enough, considering that a single save file is 6 to 8MB. Overall, the game shows great potential and gets updated regularly. There are so many things they can add to this solid foundation. I can’t wait.

Only has two missions and needs a lot of balancing. It may be a good game on release but right now there are frankly better games for the same money, like, They are Billions. In fact this game plays so much like TaB it's almost a skip from me, but time will tell what they add by release. For whatever reason I expected more accurate destructable environments - but walls just break once the HP is depleted the same way they do in any other game. There are no seige mechanics (e.g. Total War), the AI just attacks 10m of your 100m defences and everything is point and click. The art style is pretty though basic.

So this game is good. Like really good. Only took me about an hour and a half to see that it has potential. It also took me about an hour and a half to remember what it's like to be kicked in the taint with steel toe boots. This game is hard. It straight up tells you, so there's no surprise. So I go in and play the first campaign mission. Nothing crazy but it puts you through your paces. Then I meandered on over to endless mode. I just wanted a chill laid back experience so I selected the second to last easiest difficulty. The easiest makes it so no enemies spawn which I figured wouldn't be as fun. The first wave appears as I'm still building. Cool no biggie I have units. I wipe them out and continue upgrading and building my forces. My kingdom is lookin great and I like how this games flow is set up. Then the second wave appeared... A dark cloud of enemy units DOZENS of times larger than anything I've seen so far come raging from off map like a mass of starving locusts. In literal seconds my entire kingdom is no more. Balance and pacing are the two main issues I don't suggest this game. If I wanted to struggle min-max everything and be sweating beads, I'd just enter a Starcraft competition. But this game IS good and I wanna see it succeed. I suggest giving it time and waiting to see where it leads.

for a game trying to rip off "They are Billions" it does so pretty well minus a couple of aspects, which unfortunately are deal-breakers. 1. You share defensive and building resources, want a group of archers? that's fewer workers to make food to keep the archers alive (yes units starve to death, then turn into zombies and attack from wherever they died) 2. A.I pathways, they suck, you put down a tree hut, lower the zone so they don't wander too far to cut trees, so they go ahead and walk right through a raider camp, that's outside the designated zone you made for them, and guide those lovely raiders right back into your city before you're ready. 3. difficulty scale, this one is hard to be constructive about. wave one you fight maybe 20 people, wave 2 you're at about 200, wave 3 you're at about 500-600 hundred raiders including siege engines, and larger stronger enemies, wave 4? who knows, I've never been able to get that far. I even went as far as to create 6 layers of walls with about 30 archers per wall, and as many sword-men, I could fit in that time frame, they got devoured. 4. performance. it's a crap shoot. 5. variety, not a ton other than the glaring issues the game is very fun, if you like playing for 30 minutes, restarting, and playing again, kinda like an old school demo! good luck

Fun, but has fairly noticeable technical and game balance shortcomings. Technical: - Saves of more than a few hours of gameplay in Endless mode will not load within reasonable timeframe (30 min or less). This is the dealbreaker for me. - Game running for a while at higher wave sizes still suffers from significant performance drops - can be somewhat helped by restarting game, but then runs into the problem above. This is with a fairly powerful rig. Game Balance: - Diversity of units is very limited. While it appears as though there are many units (~8 infantry, 3 siege), half of them are completely replaced by later units (ie. Archer by Crossbowman, Swordsman by Spear/Hammerguy) and lose all relevance once you unlock the later units (fairly quickly). - Ballista is overshadowed by both Catapult and Trebuchet in all noticeable applications. It lacks a useful niche (like good DPS or range to counter enemy catapults) to make up for having no AoE, something that the other 2 have in droves. - Upgrade system is too barebones - upgrades generally apply to only one unit, with no further progression or synergy. Would recommend a "wait and see" approach for now - it's still a fun game with potential, but still needs a good deal of polish and rework to really shine.

This game is like an awesome blast from the past - a faithful and interesting love letter to the old Stronghold games, but with more modern graphics and control system. I did feel that this game is missing a bit of the character of the old Stronghold games - the campaign text is funny but it might at times be a little *too* silly. It can be fun to have heroic, brave, or more interesting characters thrown in the mix as well. Also, without voice acting for the campaign, it essentially boils down to watching a long cutscene of just text bubbles, which definitely made me miss how that was handled in Stronghold. This game is still early access, obviously. The campaign isn't done yet, but the 3 missions I played were a blast. I hope they incorporate more story persistent elements (for instance, I let my peasant revolt hero die accidentally and didn't see any acknowledgement of that in the cutscene dialogue, although I can chalk that up to the game being in early access. All in all, if you want a fun, fresh Stronghold-inspired game, this is a great choice! Just be aware that although the gameplay feels fairly polished, the campaign and other elements seem pretty unfinished, although there is a good foundation there and I am excited to see where they take it!

TLDR: The game is very fun and addictive but suffers from a lack of resources and ways of obtaining more and quality of life features. I managed to reach day 70 in endless mode on max difficulty, only to be beaten by not having anything to plug holes or even fix walls/towers/troops. I simply got overrun as there was no way for me to acquire more stone or iron. A trading cap of selling max 300 wood every 2 minutes is way to slow in the latter rounds. By the time a new wave arrives you may have traded 900 wood for 150 iron or 300 stone, which is fuck all in this game and barely a small wall or a few towers. Another problem is that this game works with a coin system only obtainable trough that already limited market, so you'll have to spend time on that as well, which further limits your options for stone and iron. They either need to add a more complex market system, allow (way) higher amounts to be traded at once or add a way to have unlimited stone and iron. There's also the problem that if you want to focus on enemy artillery you'll need to do it manually, as there's only an "attack nearby" and "attack strongest" option. Problem is that enemy catapults are not considered in both these options. It would be nice if there was a button to specifically focus on enemy artillery, with for example ballistas (who can use a range upgrade as right now they're very weak and useless). EDIT: according to the FAQ this is getting fixed next update. If you're looking to buy this game to see how long you'll survive don't bother (yet). It has a lot of potential and is very fun, but until then i can't really recommend it, unless you maybe do the missions, which i personally don't care about. I heard they're reworking late game economics so I'd wait until then, right now it's a no, but like i said, has a shit ton of potential.

A smoll, great RTS game really, been ages since i found one this fun and challenging. BUT I'm gonna start with a big con here, the game might be TOO challenging. It is very fast paced. You NEED to multitask, kinda all the time. You need to manage your resources, food, population while building up an army so you can defend yourself against waves and other outposts on the map. The fast paced is because you only get 3-4 in-game days before the next wave comes, which is bigger and always stronger. And at the end every single outpost you did not clear, will attack you + 5 big waves at once. Yes. You're done, it's almost impossible. It's all about management and choices really. But this aside, the game is great. The building options, upgrading, resources, population, placing your army or katapults on the walls for bigger range etc it's really well done. It's so satisfying to build an really big army and position them next and behind eachother. It's well made, for an early access game, no bugs so far, no crashing. Running the game is smooth And yeah, there's also so much potential that can make this game 10 times better. But time will tell how that turns out

There's a bug. It's annoying. I used to be able to do what I call "The Draft". That's where the day before a wave you take all the workers out of non-combat jobs like mining or forestry and make them into temporary soldiers. Get ready for a challenge. Lot of elements here. You have to a team to cut trees to built houses and buildings. Houses produce people, so then you need food. Eventually you have to upgrade the buildings and the castle to be able to get better weapons and military. Add to that, you are doing a lot of fighting with the enemy army, so it will definitely keep you busy. Plus, there are several different chapters that change the game all around. The one downside is that the game isn't complete yet. I hope they release a couple of more chapters in the campaign mode soon.

Pretty good. Haven't ran into any bugs so far. Could use more content to justify the price tag. More maps, troops, basic stuff like that. I do want to complain that the enemy path finding during raids is a little broken. You don't know if they'll come from multiple angles or a single large stream of enemies until they get into your sight. Far as I can tell, there is no way to figure it out until they're on you. You could have more than enough troops to destroy your enemies but if they happen to spawn in as multiple streams and your placements aren't good, you'll lose. It feels unbalanced.
fun

the best strat game

Mostly is a 3D low poly copy of "They are billions" or "Age of Darness". I don't have a clue why it's marketted as a tower defense, it's not. Not a bad game on it's own, but seriously lacks content for it's current price in my opinion. There is a campaign mode which is nice, but every game feels quite the same. There isn't much variety in buildings or units, and very limited way to upgrade them both.
A good RTS finally. Looking forward to the roadmap!

The game in current status is, promising; I would love to play more of it. But I wouldn't recommend my friend buying it atm because the price just can't justify the amount of content provided. I've played plenty of early access games, but come on, only 2 stages of campaign and a limb endless mode! I would say it is greatly overpriced. The game definitely shown promising aspects, but for now it is in a very EARLY early development stage I would say. If the game was priced below $10 usd I would recommend it.
Glossy and interesting at first, but under the hood is a sad story - terrible ai and pathing and very limited research.

I've only been playing for a couple of hours, but I...AM...HOOKED! Honestly, I'm only a couple of levels in but I wanted to write this review because the game is so dang good! Just now, for example, I was starting a new level. I selected everyone in the army and hit Ctrl-1 to make them a group and then I noticed "Hey, when I click and drag to select I never catch citizens!" This is BY FAR the best implementation of this must-have feature I've ever seen. The citizens of your town do anything you say just by you building what you want your castle to be. They take care of building, then staffing, chopping, baking, gardening, you name it! They take care of it and you're not caught up in micro-managing everyone. NOW you can focus on BATTLE!! Honestly, how did it take so long before someone perfected this kind of game by giving us the control we need and taking care of everything else? Its a GREAT game! If you're considering it... BUY IT!

First time playing a game like this seen a few other people play it on Twitch and always looked fun. First impression after 6 hours is I love this, its very hard even on the easiest settings but sometimes hard is very fun What I like about it: Very Simple and kinda fun tutorial Nice building and not overly complicated with every building looking the same and clicking on everything trying to figure out what it is or does. very informative tutorial that you don't really forget what you learned after it ends pretty simple research upgrades with clear directions on how to get them Diplomacy is not an option Things I dont care or like: When trying to defend against hoards my troops wanna go all over the place and not HOLD like I tell them to ( might be me not knowing how to hold them better ) Diplomacy is not an option I would give this game a solid 8/10 for the 6 hours I've played and really enjoy this little game. Beautiful game, although it needs slight tweaks and a longer campaign, the helpful devs are constantly working and have always improved gameplay to make this a really fun strategy game. good

i love this game, very enjoyable and has good potential. My main issue as of now is that even on Endless mode it feels as if you don't get enough time in between waves. The struggle between upkeep and having to worry about massive waves every 5 days to 6 days is a tad harsh. Making it every 10 days or every 15 would be great, allowing more time for defense to be built and to have town management to happen. Cant wait to see updates, and hopefully see more house types, troop types, and maybe traps to be made to help repel attacks. Even the option to build wall catapult for heavy damage on the attackers. Update: After some more time on the game I'm pretty sure the main problem is upgrading to tier 3 being very costly and the waves being way to large at a very early start. Wave 3 jumps the gun by so much and i think the waves should be every 10-15 days and not every 6. Very great game, just needs a wave nerf.

After 2 years I have to change my review. The game really does seem(ed) promising but the devs barely updating the game and instead making a new one is a joke. Do not throw away your money on this game, atleast in this state. The original review: A very promising game, I really enjoyed it, even for an early access version it's been well worth my 20€. :)

K, this game is just way too hard. Interesting game, looking forward to future development. Here are some suggestions for dev. 1. Story mod map layout is fixed, not random, and with some encounter event. 2. Tech is not only for one type of unit. For example, Sharpshooter can both benifit archer and crossbowman. 3. Tier 1 unit can be upgradged to Longbowmen or Long Sword Soldier. 4. Units' status can be slightly higher with the exp they gain from battle. 5. More souce of food (Fish should be renewable resources, and hunting ect. 6. Auto trading (making exchange of food for stone and iron in later game easier. 7. More hero units, can buff surrounding normal units. 8. Units in story mode should be different when siding with the king or the rebels. 9. Siege warfare as the attackers? (More Siege unit like scaling ladder, battering ram ect.) 10. More defence unit like moat, barbed wire and so on. 11. Magician with attack magic, Necromancer who can summon zombie warrior, and Musketeers maybe? 12. Multiplayer mode and map editor.

The game is amazing. Everything is great about it. Maybe it works for some people but I don't seem to be the only one. I'm sure the devs will iron out these issues because they seem very capable but until then this is a frustrating experience. DON'T BUY THE GAME YET IF YOU DON'T WANNA BE FRUSTRATED ABOUT CRASHES I'm still giving this a thumbs up although it's unplayable for me simple because I love love love the game!! I have just shy of 40 game play hours in, and I'm really impressed with game play and core concepts. Yes it is early access, but a truly fun early access. I look forward to what the developers add next! This is the only early access game I've found myself thinking about and looking forward to playing it, trying new strategies to survive longer... I typically loose interest in EA games after 20 or so hours in.... not the case with DNO!

Pacing and map generation are the two things killing this game right now

Great game already, but with the potential to be even better. If you like base-building and wave defense games, you'll love this. A couple of things I'd love to see added eventually: - automatic trading in the market - bigger trading airships (maybe through research) - a button to send the next wave right away - bigger maps - maybe a gold mine (could be heavily defended by rebels and you first have to free it) - unique high end fighters (maybe like a wizard or Robin Hood or a Gregor Clegane or a bard) - storage and granary lvl 4 (maybe subterranean or only buildable into a mountainside) - (or) research options to unlock bigger storage space in the respective buildings - research addons for available units (e.g., more range for archers or healing for swordsmen or stealth for healers) - maybe some reward for killing rebels (scum!) ... like 1 gold for every 50 rebels from a wave or some of these magic stones (because you can't replenish the latter once all rebel settlements have been .... liberated) - also, the records for how many days you lasted should update not just when you die, but also upon saving the game Finally, it would be cool if we could switch difficulty levels during the game (in case it's too hard or too easy) ... it could be a new category of endless game Thanks for making this.

Diplomacy Is Not An Option is a real-time city builder focused primarily on turtling, or hunkering down and building up defenses. You have to quickly transform your meager settlement and handful of units into a formidable defense. It just launched in early access, but already has a robust research tree and several tiers of upgradable buildings. Right now if features an endless survival mode and two campaign missions.

This game rocks... it's very addictive and surprisingly deep/challenging. The only problem is that it begins to crash as you progress into higher levels. I have a 3080 Laptop, so it's not an under powered PC thing. If the crashing will bug you, wishlist this until 1.0 releases. Otherwise, it's 100% worth it for fans of the defense genre.

BEWARE OF GAME! At later levels the game will spawn tens of thousands of enemies and your FPS will tank down to 0-1? fps and your system will get super HOT! I tired to CTRL+ALT+DEL my way out of it but I had to pull the plug. i7 16GB Ram RTX 2070 6GB version. Honestly the game is fun, though it does lack content but the part where it will actually damage your system is why I'm giving it the big F NO! Uninstalling.

Ive only played for a few hours but I already love the game. Its the perfect balance of a builder and a defense game. It starts out really small and Im assuming that it builds and builds based on the videos but well worth paying even full price. Rimworld is too much management for me, something like kingdoms and castles is too simple and gets boring pretty quickly. This so far really seems to be a great balance.

After several goddamned attempts to defend against the king's forces, I've finally beat them! All it costed me was literally everything I've built! The king's men may have broke down my walls, burned down my farms, pillaged my people's homes and pretty much wiped out most of my army, yet I've still won! My capitol still stands! Sure, pretty much everything's in ruins and on fire, as well as pretty much all of the people the rebellion sought to protect are slaughtered and dead, I mean goddamn, so many bodies... But. Upside. The king's army broke before the capitol did! Yay! Unfortunately it was just the mercenaries that were sent my way. The main force is still on their way apparently... But it doesn't matter! The rebellion shall continue! As soon as the developers finishes this game already... Hurry up! The king's head isn't going to off itself! On a side note, if anyone's yelling at me for spoilers, well, keep your pants on, you ain't missing much. The developers haven't finished the whole game, so the rebellion path is just one level. And ho boy, you are not ready for his mercenaries. You are very not ready. Otherwise, just stay on the path of tyranny and you'll enjoy a campaign spoiler free.
