Leaves you desperate for every second to get that building done, get those units out before the horde is coming. Difficulty is great. Feels like every time I try again- i'm learning more and making it further as I learn the minutia of the game. The game has a ton of personality in its graphics, style and campaing delivery. Extremely promising.

Pretty good they are billions clone. If you liked that game you are probably going to like this one. The mechanics are intuitive and feel solid, spells and stuff are fun to use, battles are large and fun to witness, few extra mechanics such as collecting the dead before they turn into zombies is an interesting mechanic. I like this game, however there is room for improvements. * Campaign only has 2 maps - i was really disappointed. * Campaign maps are just normal maps, i expected to play hand crafted maps and take over command of a town or a city to defend. * Performance issues in late game endless mode, even with high end pc game starts to freeze and crash. Made it to day 100 in "easy" mode. * No way to generate crystals? Thats bad, i would like to see some mechanic, e.g. religion / worth shipping a statue to generate crystals * Enemies should set up camps before the attack and if you attack it and destroy parts of it or completly the enemy wave wont be that strong * When two or more buildings are selected a promt is needed when you want to delete them. Currently it is way to easy to delete all your buildings * Archers on walls are highly inefficient to place. A mass place mode for connected walls is needed. * Building ON rocks should be possible and also very expensive. * Rivers and bridges would be cool. * Forester should be available one castle level earlier. * Cavalery should be able to run down enemies in the inital charge. Maybe upgrade to use lance and not sword. * I would like to play the other side and siege a city / castle. * More upgrades, more research and more defense mechanics would also be great. * I am missing tactics and strategies. The game is a bit shallow. Wall up, build towers, build mechanics workshop and shoot everything with catapult and such. Edit1: * A wizzard and/or a saucerer would be great. Wizzards attack from back line with spells. Saucerer uses buffs and debuffs. Edit2: I forgot to write something what i like about this game: * Food and wood generation are self suffient in mid and late game which is great. You still have to expend the base for stone and iron. * No more "carriers" from the demo. Good improvement.

Worst EA I´ve played so far. Played the tutorial which is quite OK. Started playing the campaign. First mission on medium difficulty is just a walk in the park. Playing mission two for four hours now. Even on easiest difficulty its unbeatable. Thanks to mission two I cannot refund anymore due to exceeting the two hours limit of Steam. Additionally game is extremly dull and boring. Everything takes extremly long while there´s always a time limit working against the player. Controls are completly inaccurate so you have to check back constantly. Players unit AI is a catastrophe. Some units start to attack while the rest is just standing there watching. This way enemy units can just chop down your own units bit by bit. This all leads to a frustrating high level of micromanagement of about a dozen units and buildings in total. On the other hand the gameplay lacks any kind of variation. You´re doing exactly the same thing a dozen times a minute. And last but not least the devs want some exorbitant 20€ for this dumpster fire of a game that never saw any kind of quality management. No idea how to justify that amount of money for such a dull and annoying game. So if you like inaccurate controls, frustrating micromanagement and a minimal amount of variation in gameplay this game might be the right thing for you. For everyone else: make a giant leap around it since you´re not missing out anything important.

I love this game! I happen to notice this game and I am glad I did. This is everything I love in a game. It gives me the old Empire Earth & Age of empire vibe with waves and waves of enemies. It gives tech trees to help maximize my units. It gives gives me building strategy and most of all it gives me a actually tough challenge. I really am excited to see what the future holds for this game and how the Devs improve it. I find myself wanting more and more. I didn't have any game lag or slow down. I really love every aspect of what this games brings. If I had any complaints I would say that this game can actually be really hard. The middle tier difficulty "Challenge Accepted" is quite tough at the end. You have to have to be max Town-hall level with tier 3 walls to stop the forces from bulldozing the city. Then with a crazy amount of archers or siege equipment then you should be able to stop the forces coming from all sides...Yes all sides.. Not to mention all the enemy troops that were left on the map that you didn't fight. As much as I felt frustrated in that aspect I learned to become more efficient and better. Which was a joy to play and learn from my mistakes. I think all I can ask is give me more citizens per house so I can have more soldiers. So my one criticism of this game actually turns out to be a positive. Keep doing what you are doing devs!! I am interesting in what this game brings to the strategy defense games.

Currently in early access and I'm by no means a hardcore player, but for $20, I would say wait to buy this until it gets more development. The Campaign is NOT worth bothering with at this time. I made it to the second what looked like at least a dozen towns. The final wave seems intended to kill you so that you don't know, in game, that there is only TWO campaign missions. The story scenes feel... dull, but at least it is a plot of sorts that might make for an interesting campaign later. The random maps make it impossible to plan strategies and resources when you lose and have to try again. Even though I was on the easiest difficulty the resource management made it feel like it was intended to starve my advancement arbitrarily rather than making for fun player choices. I like random maps if it feels like I have the flexibility to deal with an excess of one map feature and a near lack of the other. The problem is, the balance is so tightly defined that anything but a perfect map or expert execution will punish you without chance for recovery. That said, this game has a lot of *potential* to be fun. The systems and structure of the game work nicely, the ramping up is too high on the enemies and the resources for the players are too limited to allow a fun progression for the player, but at least the genre and the graphics are nice. Edit: I suppose I could say, recommend with caveats. The lack of campaign content still bugs me and, for me, the difficulty is still a bit too unpleasantly punishing, but for folks who like grueling survive the wave style of games, I guess it's a good pick seeing as the developers are doing great at listening to players and adding updates and the endless mode is quite playable even now.

Absolutely horrifically balanced. I'm not overly familiar with games like they are billions etc. so when i got my ass handed to me, I assumed it was due to missing experience with this type of game. Turned down the difficulty and got swamped even more. tried several times on several difficulties and no change. The maps are randomly generated, so naturally the difficulty is as well. Whether or not you get access to natural choking points, such as cliffs or water, is up to the cointoss. Even the Campaign maps are fully random. I'm not sure how the devs are guiding their difficulty curve if they can't be arsed to create even the Campaign maps. Enemies come from random directions and you get very little warning time as to where they'll spawn, so reactively building up a defense is out of the question. Building up an all-purpose omnidirectional defense is also out of the question because you can't have a defending army AND generate the required ressources in time. You can build up the defense if you dedicate the entire settlement to ressource generation or you can have an army to use the defenses you had no resources to build. On a concept level, the game is good. But it needs significant balancing passes before it plays well. as things stand right now: 3/10 do not buy.

One of those games where, in its current state, I wish I could give a neutral score. This is obviously a style of game that's been done before, but there's something compelling about fighting off waves of endless hordes. And therein lies the problem. The difficulty ramps up far more quickly than it's possible to cope with. I feel as though the game needs to be more balanced, so you're not overwhelmed by wave 4 on the easiest setting. Of course, it could just be me, and I might well be rubbish at these sort of games, but DINAO just makes it a bit too hard for me. Graphically, well, it's what you'd expect from a game like this. Nice, neat, cute. Sound is nice, with the gruff voices of your soldiers sounding like Englishmen, which is a nice touch for an Englishman like me! Interface is fine, although I'd like to know how much food I was producing/consuming, and it would be nice if the fish regenerated over time. And the forests. Maybe through further research that kind of thing is possible. I'd like to see a larger research tree, but I think that until I can work out a reliable tactic, I'm going to be beaten by wave 4/5 every time, so that's not much time to research new tech. I wish it was more forgiving, which would lead to longer games, and it would be great to have a massive battle combating a massive base that's been gradually constructed over waves. Nice to see a big base being torn down after a lengthy game than a small base being ripped to shreds in 15 mins. That said, I like it, hope it gets developed further, and it's one of those games that I will keep on coming back to.

Very good survival strategy game. In a similar manner with 'Billions' - you build the base, train troops, explore the map, build defenses, survive waves of enemies - before the final assault. Signature features for this title would be: Resources are not endless - trees will be cut down for wood, Stone doesn't grow on mountains and neither do Iron. Gold can be acquired by trade only - and the art for the trading sequence is magnificent. Art is very cute. The game runs smoothly. The story is solid - dark humor suits the narrative quite well. At this moment the game has campaigned with 3 missions and 3 endless modes. Following the Roadmap posted by Devs: I would love to see a survival mode, while the game is in EA. Also - not sure if there will be a coop mode.

This is a review of the game as it was on initial early access release. It contains an endless mode and two campaign missions - further campaign missions are promised. Graphics: The game is gorgeous and runs well on my machine, you can scroll to a very low level of detail and it's enjoyable to watch your little peons run around doing their thing. Gameplay: This game has 3 game modes and the experience is drastically different between them. The 'easy' game mode is the only one where as a player you can actually enjoy building up your settlement and taking time to watch battles/workers. Medium and hard scale up with limited starting resources, more regular and larger waves of enemies. If you want a challenge you will get it in spades. It can be brutal. Having to manually collect magic crystals forces you out of your turtle which is a good bonus for cowardly players like me. HOWEVER - if you enjoy building up a settlement you risk bouncing off this game on anything other than easy as the frantic racing around the screen desperately micro-managing units in your army for peak efficiency, building specific builds in exactly the right order will leave little time for 'enjoying' the colony builder aspect. So you would be right to approach this as a medieval They Are Billions. Content? I'm a little disappointed - the endless mode and two campaign missions feels slightly lightweight. However the game mechanics and breadth of unit types/buildings and enemies I have seen are very impressive and show an extremely sturdy start. Don't leave bodies lying around. They get back up and start eating your peons.

I bought this game ages ago and thought it might just be another early access cash-in after seeing no progress for a while. I was wrong - 1.0 is amazing. The amount of variety even in the first few missions is crazy; it's no longer just the one gimmick "fend off millions of peasants". The mechanics are great, building up your base is a joy, it's fun to build up and use your army, and the sheer scale of the large attacks is quite incredible. I see a lot of reviews complaining that Mission 3 (the build boats mission I assume) is a crazy difficulty spike. If you are familiar with how the resource and building system works (which is much more intuitive nowadays and you should pick it up after a couple of games), the mission shouldn't be much trouble. If you use your brain, look at the objectives, see what is required, and act accordingly. The objectives ask you to make a big army to go on the boats, so I focused on making a large army quite early rather than building fortifications, and the mission was no trouble at all. Pro tip for players struggling vs catapults: Just save your magic and use the beam whenever a catapult appears - it'll save you a lot of trouble.

A pretty good They Are Billions clone with several changes that I think improve the game a lot. Has speed settings (unlike TAB) and pause and reasonable zoom (unlike Age of Darkness). Its unique point is the physics simulation, which mostly means if an enemy changes speed or direction during the travel of a projectile you'll miss, shooting over obstacles will reduce accuracy and range, and if your siege engines don't have clear shots they'll often impact terrain dealing no damage to the enemy hordes. While zombies do exist in the game the main enemies you will defend against are actually revolting peasants who have their own siege engines, which can be interesting. The game has several resources of which two are infinite on the map eventually (food and wood, limited in the demo but at tier 2 you can get infinite food and tier 3 infinite wood), two are finite on the map but can be traded for (stone and iron) and one that can only be traded for (gold). The fact that tier one defenses and units as well as some tier 2 units can be recruited for only food and/or wood keep them relevant longer. The game is somewhat buggy currently, and performance apparently is severely impacted on certain CPUs (12th gen i7s I've seen repeatedly), but in the ten hours I've played during the course of playing prior to this review I've found two; A wave spawning on an enclosed area that did not have a path to the rest of the map and the game crashing around day 42. Try the demo, if the basic gameplay appeals to you it's better in the main game due to the content tiers 2 and 3 add. If you don't like the demo at all you probably won't like the game.

A mixture of Age of Empires, Stronghold, They Are Billions and Civilization. And the mixture is in very correct proportions. Gameplay - Many buildings of different levels and their purposes. Variable combat units. Tree of development of strengthenings. Excellent physical model and hence the behavior of the units. Ability to use terrain as a tactical advantage. And that's all training and the first mission. It is extremely pleasant that the main emphasis is placed on the control of troops, since only them need to be ordered, while workers are replenished daily (not always convenient, since sometimes you need to get them right now, however, on the other hand, such an implementation requires a competent expenditure of manpower ) and do everything themselves, only the construction of the necessary buildings is required. Graphics - Very nice low-poly art with, most importantly, the ability to change the viewing angles and camera range during the game, which is sometimes extremely useful in strategies. Music - Atmospheric and fits perfectly with the setting. Plot - So far, only the beginning, but the plot and its presentation hooked from the first minutes. The plot itself is presented in the form of pleasant sketches between missions (similar to the briefing in Stronghold, but with graphics on the game engine). Also a separate respect to the developers for great humor. 10 hillbillies with a pitchfork out of 10

Another fine entry in the colony defense genre. Love They Are Billions and Age of Darkness? You'll love this one. It adds some fun new mechanics such as special player abilities (summoning dark knights is fun) without being OP. Workers need to do all the building instead of just throwing down a building. And best of all, the game doesn't take itself overly seriously. From the more blocky art style to the humor in the (currently short) campaign. The mechanics feel smooth for the most part for being an Early Access title, and while there are a few bugs and glitches, there's nothing game breaking. They fixed and changed a number of things from the demo that shows they are serious about their game. And the promise of further improvements will keep me coming back to this title for a while to come.

THE GAME IS BRILLIANT, I know its the early access. I'm a BIG FAN of aoe 2/3/4, stronghold 1, warcraft 3, The big plus of this game is that's kind of unique. I would suggest adding more resources to fish stone iron as its super tough on endless mode even on labirinth of pain ( i think without certain build order a lot of people can get in HUGE trouble as I have seen first gameplays). I found some bug/glitch that sometimes when i destroy enemy camp still few units spawns few secs after it so it can be a bit decisive if you moved to the town center and dont realise enemy kills your archers ( happened to me more than 10 times in 8h of gameplay), sometimes also enemies after hit with trebuchet/ catapult dissapear for a moment (looks like its no animation when these units try to get up which also can be confusing when you push enemy further). Anyone seeing this don't even consider to not buy this game because its definitely worth to wait to fix it. As I mentioned before stone/iron could be atleast 400-500 resources as in early game is super difficult to get more places to loot these resources. I think once devs will receive more feedback will be easier to them as well to change the game for better! This review is not sponsored and once again THIS GAME IS MASTERPIECE! BIG SHOUTOUT TO DEVS, YOU MADE ME CRY, I LOVE THE GAME SO MUCH.

A medieval style strategy in which we will have to take on the role of the king-ruler and lead an entire state. We will have to solve the problems of peaceful villagers so they do not revolt, deal with economic issues so that the settlement flourished and developed, develop new territories to increase the demography of our population and create your own army to fight the crowds of various enemies who will make every effort to destroy our kingdom. Every action we take as king may have different consequences, so it all depends on us and the people living in our kingdom may either love us as a leader and live happily ever after, or hate us and try to dethrone us. The game will please us with unhurried but thoughtful gameplay, pleasant visual style and relaxing soundtrack. What more do you need to spend a pleasant evening.

I love RTS. And don't skip this game. Diplomacy is Not an Option is a fairly typical game of its genre. Build city, walls, army, resource extraction. But this game stands out visually. We've been lucky to enjoy great games in this genre like They Are Billions, Age of Darkness, Conan Unconquered, Alien Marauder, etc. Now we get one more entry to this busy field of games and luckily, if you are a fan of this game type, you should act now to enjoy this solid entry to the field. This game has nice graphics, solid gameplay, and is real joy to play. I am excited for further development but from what we have already, this is a good buy and it is well-priced. Enjoy!

The core gameplay is there. It really is. I like the unit variety, the tech tree, the upgrade tiers, being able to build tall instead of wide in case you get a good spawn with lots of close resources.... I just wish that more of the campaign had been available today. I mean, I know it's early access and all but they show you this really badass map with all of these villages and cities and even multiple continents...then you beat the 2nd level and you are done. That was a real bummer. I'm sure many people will be perfectly happy with endless mode but that's not what I'm here for. I hope they keep up on development.

Diplomacy is Not an Option - This is yet another great sandbox-style city builder. Excellent, simplified and elaborated graphics, nothing superfluous. Good gameplay without which there is nowhere and beautiful to the ears melody. Throughout the game I have not encountered a single bug or minus, if there were any minuses, only not significant. After 2 hours, it's very polished for an Early Access game. Already at this stage it has a campaign as well as an endless mode. It's already far ahead of where 'They Are Billions' was at its initial early access state. It's a minor thing, but the voice acting is so much more bearable than TAB. There's no stilted actors pretending to be British, or overly hammy voicelines. The best comparison would be Warcraft 3 humans, just the right combination of goofy and serious. The only negative I can think of is that the difficulty is not as tweakable as TAB, and the maximum is likely not as hard as TAB is at max settings. The lowest difficulty is much easier than TAB for comparison's sake. I greatly look forward to future updates.
Omg this is amazing game!

The game is already very entertaining and has great potential. I would like to see a roadmap or at least a list of all the upcoming key features.

despite not having top notch graphics, i have to admit i am surprised but i really like the simplistic graphical style as well. the game runs smoothly and the animations are fine. the AI is not very smart but let's be honest, no game in this genre has decent AI. so the AI is very well comparable to other games of this genre and therefore i think one should not expect too much from it. having said that this game is really fun! i like the combination of stronghold and games like they are billions or age of darkness. if you like building up your own castle, while having to reach for a limited amount of resources and while having to face big waves of enemies then this game is clearly for you. the game is officially in early access but it does not feel like early access when you play it. it feels polished. i like how the devs listened to feedback from the demo and i am looking forward for the next upcoming updates. in my opinion the price is fair because i am enjoying the game and i am totally fine with supporting the devs in order to let them continue to work on this game. i recommend to try it out yourself
Just played a little and it isn't boring or one-dimensional at all like I was expecting it to be, but rather has a surprising amount of depth. Giving me Age of Empires vibes, not bad.

Great RTS with good animations, combat and resource management. Hoping to see many more friendly/Enemy units and buildings, better optimisation, more micro management and customisation. The potential is massive. 7/10

Fantastic Wave Defense/City Builder Game If you like wave defense, city building strategy games you'll really like this one. This game feels complete immediately upon release into early access, from top to bottom it is worth $25. Thank you dev(s) for a fantastic strategy game!

Quite a fun game! Visuals and art style allow for a fun and nicely executed spin on the survival strategy genre, good job! Amount of content is not that great, but for early access, at this price I'd say its worth supporting this developer. There is a good foundation here to build something really cool, and that was showed ever since the demo. Concern with removing carriers from the game is that it takes away a lot of depth, where there isn't that much in the game as it is now, but hopefully new systems will emerge to replace this mechanic. At the price right now - You are buying a fun experience and supporting a seemingly new dev team. At a sale - Must buy.

Classic strategy, get resources, explore the skill tree, build your own castle and... "Kill 1,000,000 Chinese!!!" Fights here with a very large number of units look spectacular. One bad thing is the graphics. I understand that this is such a style, but it is too Minecraft.

This game is pretty difficult, but it's also really fun and it just feels great to play. I also have to mention the soundtrack as well, it's uh, beautiful. It's so relaxing hearing the stringed instruments while the birds are chirping and the wind is blowing. I really didn't think I'd be talking about the soundtrack mainly in the review but good grief it makes you yearn for the springtime.

The game is fascinating and addictive with its mechanics of the development of the state. I liked that this is not a simple economic strategy, but with the ability to manage your army as one warrior and the whole army. Build, develop, defend and attack!

Essentially, this takes my favorite part of any RTS, building up a town and planning a really solid defense, and emphasizes it over offence. So far, the full game lives up to the demo, and then some. This feels like a very feature complete early access, if that's a point of concern.
Just finished the first mission and had lots of fun so far! Also no crashes, bugs or other technical problems occured. Stoked for more!
